characters: THE WALLS OF THIS ROOM ARE SPLATTERED WITH BLOOD
ALEX AND VICTOR AT THE TABLE
THE PALE VISAGE OF JIMMY DOYLE, THE BLOND CHOPPE
A NEW YORK CITY BUS MOVES INTO FRAME
THE STEPS OF A TENEMENT BUILDING
NEWSPAPER PHOTO SEEN THROUGH MAGNIFYING GLASS
THE FACE OF A BEDRAGGLED BUM
A SUNLIT SKY BRACKETED BY TWO CITY SKYSCRAPERS

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT
dialogues.text: The East Village -- a part of New York's Lower East Side. At this hour the streets are almost empty. It's unusually chilly for early autumn and steam rises from the occasion manhole cover. There is a faint flicker from a neon sign the distance. WE MOVE IN toward a tenement building, completely dark except for a single lighted window. CLOSER on the lighted window. WE CAN SEE a MAN in blue jeans cross the room, sw on a television set and flop down in a bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The opposite of clean and neat. Boxes piled high, a gener disheveled atmosphere. On the walls, movie size posters o Jack Webb, Frank Lovejoy, Eddie Constantine. The man in blue jeans, ALEX RADA, is watching ETouch of E on television. (It is the scene in which Orson Welles wan into a seedy Mexican bordello run by Marlene Dietrich). Rada fluffs up a pillow, tosses it behind his head and wa the action on screen.

dialogues.speaker: WELLES
dialogues.text: "Have you forgotten your old friend?"

dialogues.speaker: DIETRICH
dialogues.text: "I told you we're closed."

dialogues.speaker: WELLES
dialogues.text: "I'm Hank Quinlin."

dialogues.speaker: DIETRICH
dialogues.text: "...I didn't recognize you. You should lay off those candy bars."

dialogues.speaker: WELLES
dialogues.text: "It's either the candy or the hootch. I must say I wish it was your chili I was getting fat on. Anyway, you're sure looking good." Dietrich stares, a cigarette dangling from her lips.

dialogues.speaker: DIETRICH
dialogues.text: "...You're a mess, honey." On this, Rada MOVES INTO FRAME, switches off the TV.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By the night table -- Rada reaches for a wrinkled newspap He sits precariously on the edge of the bed, the paper re on his legs as he gazes off at nothing in particular. Holding up the newspaper now, hands outstretched trying t it. He's obviously having trouble focusing -- a man in ne of glasses. A few more moments. Squinting. He tosses it a We now see Alex close up for the first time. He is sandy- rudely handsome, still young -- but it is youth tempered of battered dignity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Light from the bedroom filters in to illuminate the room. moves toward the refrigerator, opens it. Very little insi We are struck by the freezer, it approximates the Antarct pack. There is something in there all right, but the cake won't not relinquish it. His foot braced against the bott of the refrigerator for leverage, he yanks and tugs at so frozen thing. Can't dislodge it. Finally gives up. Moving around the kitchen. Alex trips over something larg and pliable. We HEAR a GROAN.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Shit, Victor, are you still here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Balloons. Lots of NOISE. A political rally is in progress On the platform, a woman in her mid fourties acknowledges CHEERS of the CROWD. She wears a well-tailored outfit and a politician's smile. This is DELANEY LYNCH, the new sena candidate of the New York State Democratic party. She moves to the podium. Tremendous enthusiasm. The band strikes up Happy Days are Here Again.

dialogues.speaker: DELANEY
dialogues.text: (looking around, milking it for all it's worth) Well...it's been a long night...and a tough primary...but we've finally made it. A ROAR from the crowd.

dialogues.speaker: BEHIND THE PODIUM
dialogues.text: Delaney Lynch's inner circle: PAT CADELL, DAVID GARTH types. Also some acolytes. Hangers on. They are beaming, applauding fervently. We move through this group, HOLD on FRANK WILLIS, press spokesman for Delaney Lynch. He looks tired, but we're not sure if it's from the long night or tough living. ANGLE ADJUSTS TO INCLUDE PROFESSOR KATHARINE RAINES. She standing next to Frank Willis and they exchange a knowing a savvy nod. Katharine is a good ten years younger than t of Delaney Lynch's set. Her look and manner, like her aca credentials, are impeccable.

dialogues.speaker: THE CROWD
dialogues.text: as though it were New Year's Eve.

dialogues.speaker: DELANEY LYNCH
dialogues.text: steps back and brings her husband ALFRED to the podium. A fifty-five he is a Wall Street don, and a power in this c She kisses him. They wave to the crowd. Delaney raises Alfred's arms above his head in a gesture of triumph, alm as though he, too, were on the ticket.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK WILLIS AND KATHARINE RAINES
dialogues.text: Frank leans in toward Katharine, slips her a piece of pap (Throughout the remainder of the scene, Delaney Lynch's speech will OVERLAP and play UNDER Frank and Katharine's

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: This is all the way downtown.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: (not looking at Katharine, but to the podium) Would you rather I do it?

dialogues.speaker: DELANEY LYNCH, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (measured cadence) Let us bring together this party... (more cheers) ...to face the challenge before us. (beat) We intend to run hard, to fight hard -- and when we're elected -- to work hard for the people of the State of New York---

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: (above the din) No. I'd better go.

dialogues.speaker: DELANEY LYNCH, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: ---We seek freedom, but not at the expense of responsibility. We seek fairness, but not at the expense of justice...We seek peace, but not at the expense of diligence---

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: Frank, are you sure?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: He can find her, Katie. But, do me a favor, don't ask me if I'm sure..of anything.

dialogues.speaker: DELANEY LYNCH, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: ---And when we sit in the Senate of the United States...this time, this time, It - Will - Not - Be - Politics as usual. CHEERS.

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: Cynic 'til the end, Frank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A limousine pulls up to the curb followed by two black re cars. The Lynch's chauffeur, JIMMY DOYLE, steps out of th limo, positions himself by the car's back door. He is in livery, standing stiffly, cap under one arm. With his clo cropped blond hair and boyish face, he gives the appearan a Wermacht conscript. Delaney, Alfred, and their entourage emerge from the hote Although we cannot hear what they are saying above the GENERAL CLAMOR, Delaney and Katharine Raines are deeply i in conversation. Delaney's arm is wrapped around Katharin shoulder; Katharine is poking the air with her finger to a point. Delaney pauses as a FEW PHOTOGRAPHERS approach. She flash a smile and the 'okay sign' for the early edition.

dialogues.speaker: FADE UP
dialogues.text: A hand moves in and presses one. We HEAR the slow WHIRRIN of an old elevator.

dialogues.speaker: PULL BACK TO REVEAL
dialogues.text: Katharine Raines, head tilted slightly upward in the dire of her ascent.

dialogues.speaker: THE END OF A HALLWAY
dialogues.text: Katharine reaches a door, pulls out a set of keys, unlock

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The mid morning sun slices beams of light through gaps in curtains. There is no sound as Katharine moves about on a carpet. She is obviously looking for something. .* sun and no sound give a surreal feeling

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks under the bed. By the dresser. Night stand. Fin nothing. She half looks into the bathroom- not much chanc

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Checks around again. She moves off into the kitchen, but stay in this room in LONG SHOT, getting a sense of the place-- well kept, almost prim. Katharine comes back into the room, moves toward the door one more look over her shoulder. She exits.

dialogues.speaker: TRAVELLING
dialogues.text: with Katharine as she checks a piece of paper, looks to t numbers on storefronts and doorways. She stops at an old tenement, the ground floor occupied by the offices of 'TH UKRAINIAN FREEDOM PARTY.' To the right of this faded sign an entrance way leading up a flight of stairs. Katharine hesitates, taking it all in. Again looks to the piece of paper with the address.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Older immigrants. Artists. Downtown types. The Veleshka i gathering place for an eclectic clientele -- a popular, o eatery complete with a fountain and newspapers sold insid Alex Rada is at one of the tables wolfing down breakfast. Through the window, we can see Katharine across the stree She turns to CAMERA, then moves toward the tenement and through the entrance. A broad faced Slavic looking WAITRESS trudges over to Alex's table.

dialogues.speaker: WAITRESS/LESIA
dialogues.text: Good, Alex?

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: (still eating) Like always, Lesia. Home cooking.

dialogues.speaker: LESIA
dialogues.text: Yeah, yeah, home cooking. Alex, we make some stuffed cabbage. I put some in a bag for you, okay Alex?

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Fine. She wipes down the table. At the cash register, FATHER ST an Orthodox priest, buys the Ukrainian paper, Svoboda. He strokes his grayish beard and slowly wags his finger at A Alex smiles, Lesia turns around.

dialogues.speaker: LESIA
dialogues.text: Alex, you see in the paper? They say a riot in Kharkiv.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Can't read Ukrainian like I used to. (an afterthought) Don't you think the print in those papers is kind of small?

dialogues.speaker: LESIA
dialogues.text: Shouldn't lose touch with the homeland, Alex. Maybe comes a revolution.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Cavalry charge by the Hetman, Lesia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Katharine is at an apartment door. A badly stenciled sign in black spray paint reads, 'RADA INVESTIGATIONS.' She RINGS the BELL. No answer. Again. Nothing. Slowly she turns the knob and pushes the door open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Katharine is in the living room now, although it aspires be an office of sorts. It's as mangy as in the beginning scenes-- Men's close and general EstuffR are scattered ab

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: Hello...Mr. Rada? Sees another door, walks cautiously toward it.

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: THE DOOR
dialogues.text: it swings open.

dialogues.speaker: A FACE
dialogues.text: A grubby, bedraggled face of a man is behind it.

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: startled, frightened-- she backs up, loses her balance an half falls on to a desk.

dialogues.speaker: THE MAN
dialogues.text: he inches forward. He wears a tattered sweatshirt with th words 'Thank You Paine Webber' emblazoned on it. Katharine is frozen for a moment, but just a for a moment holds her arm up to her face protectively, raises her leg to kick out. We HEAR FOOTSTEPS on the stairs. Alex saunters through th door holding a brown paper bag in one hand. He looks to Katharine, then to this raggedy man. The man (VIC D'AMATO) waves at Alex.

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: (an ear to ear toothless grin) Hello, Alex! Alex walks past Katharine as though she weren't there. He Victor the brown bag.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: From the Veleshka. Stuffed cabbage. Victor opens the bag, sniffs inside.

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: Thanks, Alex. Alex pats him gently on the back, turns to Katharine:

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: And who might you be? Still a bit stunned, she gawks at these two for a beat. Composes herself. Then, as if to restore her dignity:

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: Doctor Katharine Raines. She brushes herself off.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: (extending his hand) Alex Rada. Sorry about Victor. Got no place to go, really. He's a good guy, so I let him stay when he needs to. Victor is now sprawled on the couch, making a horrible me of the stuffed cabbage with his fingers. ALEX (cont'd.) (to Victor, almost a yell) You're a good guy, aren't ya Victor?

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: Yeah, Alex. Katharine sits, takes out a cigarette, lights it.

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: (without looking up) Tell him not to drip. Alex takes the hint, sits behind the desk across from Kat

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Victor, why don't you take that into the kitchen? Victor obliges. ALEX (cont'd.) (to Katharine) He fought Carmen Basilio once, got knocked out in the twelfth. (a beat, she's clearly not interested) Is this a house call, Doctor?

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: (a bit sheepishly) Actually, my doctorate's in Political Science. (a pull from the cigarette) There was no message on your answering machine so I...I'd like to hire you, Mr. Rada.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: ...For?

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: I'd like you to find someone. A student. My graduate assistant.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Okay...what's your interest? How about her parents?

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: She has no relatives that I know of. Just some friends at N.Y.U., that's where I teach. They're worried about her. (a beat) She was special, Mr. Rada, and I'd like to help. I just want to know what happened to her, I feel responsible Alex is studying her, realizing how beautiful she is. He a pencil, drums it the on desk-- he's not quite sure he's buying all this. A moment of silence.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: I've been meaning to get it fixed... the answering machine. Tried the police?

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: Yes. She's not in any of the hospitals or the morgue. The party line is that anyone over twenty-one can pack up and leave, and they can't do anything. But she didn't. Alex still drumming with the pencil. KATHARINE (cont'd.) She liked to hang around the clubs, and bars down here. (a smack of sarcasm) Your bailiwick, I understand.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: You said, she EwasR special. Was?

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: (beat) No one's seen her for almost a week, Mr. Rada Alex stops drumming, tosses the pencil aside.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Okay, I get $350 a day plus any expenses. If there are any... Katharine, stubs out her cigarette, surveys the 'office', looks to Rada skeptically. It's Alex's turn to be embarra

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: All right, how about three hundred? (Katharine, still staring) Okay, we're having a sale, it's Ukrainian Flower Day...two fifty.

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: (slight nod of agreement) Just for the record, Mr. Rada, I can afford a great deal more than I'm paying you. But I don't like cost overruns.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Fine, as long as...uh...we understand each other.

dialogues.speaker: TRAVELLING
dialogues.text: with Alex and AMY SALOMON, a young woman in her early twe Amy walks with her hands folded, a concerned expression. In b.g. we can see the buildings of New York University.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: Well, she isn't around very much.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: She stayed out late? Liked to party?

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: Sure. But I mean I practically have the room to myself. I see her maybe once or twice a week.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Where do you think she goes?

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: (shrugs) I don't know, Sue is...you know, private.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: How about her friends?

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: She mentioned some guys, brought one up once. Brian, I think. (a sensual smile) Primo cute.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: How cute?

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: About as cute as you. Shorter though, maybe 5-10. Dark hair, blue eyes -- nicer than yours.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: (straight ahead) I'll need a picture of Susan. And I'd like to take a look around if it's okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alex is rummaging around, opening a closet, picking throu some paint brushes on a dresser, etc.

dialogues.speaker: AMY, (V.O)
dialogues.text: I think I have a yearbook somewhere. Is that okay?

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Yeah, fine. No parents? Relatives? Amy strides into view with the yearbook. Rips out a page, hands it to Alex.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: An aunt and uncle on Long Island, they brought her up. Alex is surprised, both by her answer and the act of ripp page. Amy notices.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: (smiling, perhaps a bit too seductively) That's okay, I don't need it. She moves to Alex, presses up against him as she points o photo in the yearbook.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: of a delicate, strikingly beautiful woman. Under the phot the name 'SUSAN D. BLAKE.'

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Do you know where on Long Island, Amy? Alex moves to a rolled up poster by the wall.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: No, I sure don't. She called them a couple of times, but I don't know the town. He unrolls it, takes a long look. It's a poster of Che, the standard-- showing Gueverra in beret and bandellero.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: The two of you discuss politics? She talk much about the Reds? He re-rolls it, props it back up against the wall.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: (incredulous) Sorry? Reds!? This reaction is not all together new to Alex. He respond almost wearily.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Yeah. Reds. You know, the guys who want to suck up your individuality. Turn you into Robbie the robot for the State...Reds. Amy's mouth agape. She can't believe what she's just hear Really made a mistake with this guy.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: (a distinctly different tone) The poster's mine. Sue isn't into politics much.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: So what she doing in Political Science?

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: Sue isn't in Poli Sci, she's in the Art School.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: (not sure he's understood her) Wait...you mean she's not Doctor Raines' graduate assistant?

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: No. She helped Professor Raines with some project or something, I know that. Maybe she took a media course with her. For a moment they stare, not knowing what to make of one another. Finally:

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: Look, I've got class in a little while, okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SHOOTING ACROSS a busy street, WE SEE Alex emerge from a TOBACCO SHOP. He heads toward a building up the block.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A sign on the wall reads, 'REGISTRAR'. Alex walks through a set of doors next to the sign and WE FOLLOW Alex into--

dialogues.speaker: THE RECEPTION AREA
dialogues.text: A large room with a long counter at one end. Some STUDENT mill about. An open area behind with A FEW CLERKS at computer screens. An older WOMAN is at the counter, a pair of glasses attac to a black elastic band hangs from her neck. Alex pulls a pipe from his pocket, sidles up to the count smiles his most ingratiated smile.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Excuse me, I wonder if you could help. I need the home address of one my students.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: And you are...?

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Professor Raines. Poli Sci. The woman pushes away a small microphone attached to a fl stand, begins pecking away at the terminal in front of he

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: (not looking up) Professor, you'll have to go to your own department for that. Sliding on her glasses, she reads something off the termi A slight smirk.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Our computer's down. Secretary's at lunch...and it's sort of an emergency. She looks to Alex, then to the screen. Wholesale skeptici Alex pushes the smile. Reluctantly she acquiesces.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: Student's name?

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Blake, Susan D. She types it in, waits.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: There is no home address. There's a contact. A Mr. Harry Della Famina---

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Just a second. Alex lays the pipe down, takes a pen from the counter and begins to write.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: Ready professor?...Mr. Harry Della Famina, 1643 Derby Drive, Plainview, Long Island...516-KL5-1950. (looking up) Okay?

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Yes, well thanks very much. You've been a great help.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: (an aside) I'll bet.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: as he moves toward the double doors.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: She looks to Alex, to the computer screen, to Alex again. for the microphone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The woman's VOICE over the LOUDSPEAKER: (V.O.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Professor EKatharineR Raines, will you please pick up your pipe at the registrar's desk. Alex MOVES INTO FRAME. Stops for just a beat, then exits, closing the door behind him. HOLD ON DOOR.

dialogues.speaker: A DARK SCREEN
dialogues.text: A car emerges from the depths of a garage. As CAMERA PULL BACK we can see a 'Hertz Rental' sign and the car turning onto a city street. Alex is driving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alex's rental moving along. Not too much traffic.

dialogues.speaker: THE EXPRESSWAY- FARTHER ON
dialogues.text: The car moves past a sign reading: 'Plainview - Exit 2 Mi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alex is listening to the RADIO-- the tail of a campaign a for PETER VERESS, Delaney Lynch's opponent in the Senate race. He pushes the buttons, gets some fusion jazz (maybe Oingo Boingo) -- this is more to his liking. About a mile down the road we can see an overpass. We HEA what sounds like a faint RUSH OF WIND. Then, a SUDDEN CRU as another car careens into the rental car's side. For a moment, Alex freezes, not realizing what has happen He glances to the side, sees the other car move ahead.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: What the fuck...? He holds tight to the wheel, trying to control the car. On the shoulder now, and very quickly the concrete of the overpass rushes up to meet him. The SOUND of BRAKES again the gravel.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX'S CAR
dialogues.text: it SMASHES into the abutment. Front lights smashed in, the hood bent damaged. WE HOLD. Alex emerges, dazed, but okay. He looks down the highway. The other car has pulled over. Alex squints at it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: the other car in the distance. He can't quite make its de never mind the plate-- just some kind of black vehicle to It abruptly takes off again down the highway.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX'S RUMPLED CAR
dialogues.text: He surveys the damage to the rental, peeks down the highw for one more look. He's not sure what to make of this. Alex moves to touch the car, runs his hand over hood. He toward the road, then again to the car, his hands now on hips. Confusion.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: I knew I should've gotten collision. Slowly he gets back into the car, SLAMS the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alex's rumpled rental moves down the block. It stops in f of a house which looks almost identical to the others on street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alex is speaking with a ROBERTA DELLA FAMINA, a slim, self-conscious woman in her early fifties. she doesn't make eye contact easily.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERTA
dialogues.text: My husband's out on the patio. Won't you come this way? Alex follows her through the living room and into the kit Roberta reaches for a small towel, wipes her hands before ushering Alex to a rear screen door. She opens it for him but stays inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HARRY DELLA FAMINA sits on one of those aluminum framed c held together by thick strands of woven vinyl. His leg is outsretched and raised up on a squared stool. He is a man who once must have been tough-- now he is old beyond his years, a distinctive yellow pallor to his face. Della Famina is playing solitaire on a large outdoor tabl and cheating at it. Next to him, a bottle of scotch and t glasses. He looks up as Alex steps out on the patio.

dialogues.speaker: DELLA FAMINA
dialogues.text: ...I was a little surprised to get your call, Mr. Rada. Susan again. Alex moves to shake his hand. Instead Della Famina pours a scotch.

dialogues.speaker: DELLA FAMINA
dialogues.text: You'll forgive me if I don't get up -- phlebitis...that's not the half of it, either. Scotch?

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: No thanks. I'm trying to keep my car on the road. Alex looks around at the back yard, the separate garage behind-- pleasant middle class surroundings. He sits in an aluminum chair opposite Della Famina.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Nice place you've got. Della Famina reads Alex's face for a hint of sarcasm. Can find any, but supplies plenty of his own.

dialogues.speaker: DELLA FAMINA
dialogues.text: You like it, Mr. Rada? Built up from nothing. Outdoor patio, mid-size Ford in the garage... plastic swimming pool in the summer... Now, how can you beat that, Mr. Rada -- the American Dream. He takes in Alex's discomfort, almost relishes it. DELLA FAMINA (cont'd) ...But you've come about Susan, haven't you?

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Uh huh. You knew she was missing?

dialogues.speaker: DELLA FAMINA
dialogues.text: Missing? Not likely. Run off with some bum maybe.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Is she's your niece, Mr. Della Famina?

dialogues.speaker: DELLA FAMINA
dialogues.text: My sister's girl. She and her husband died in --------, remember that? (a moment in thought) ...He was a fuckin' prick anyway. Della Famina sets the solitaire deck aside. DELLA FAMINA (cont'd.) Hope you're getting paid well for this. You're wasting your time. The girl's always been trouble. (leaning in toward Alex) ...Once, I caught her in the garage, putting on a show for the local boys, playing with it, too...Know how old she was?...Eleven. Alex doesn't want to hear this, doesn't like this man.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: (pressing on) Mr. Della Famina, has she been around lately? Know any of her boyfriends? Maybe, where they live? Della Famina downs some scotch, looks to the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: DELLA FAMINA
dialogues.text: Roberta! (to Alex) She doesn't come around. Can't stand her uncle. Roberta comes from the kitchen with a tray of cheese and crackers, each neatly topped with a piece of pimento. She places it on the table. Della Famina is waiting for her to leave.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: (takes one; looks to Roberta) Thanks, Mrs. Della Famina. A tight smile from Roberta. She exits.

dialogues.speaker: DELLA FAMINA
dialogues.text: I took good care of Susan, you know. My brother wouldn't take her in. Too busy with his catalog sales-- product fulfillment, they call it... Took his company public last year. Doesn't give a flying piss about me, though. (checks himself; empties the glass of scotch) ...Always flaunting it. She had no gratitude. Gave her everything, and wasn't getting it much in return. I was like a real father to her. (beat) A father has rights, Mr. Rada. Alex bristles at this remark.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: I bet it must be tough...being a father. Beautiful daughter like that, all those healthy young men around. (looking to Della Famina's leg) I could see how she'd give you trouble after a while.

dialogues.speaker: DELLA FAMINA
dialogues.text: (an involuntary shudder) What the EfuckR is that supposed to mean?

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Hey, take it in the spirit it was given. Alex stands, grabs another one of the pimento things. Sta toward the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Don't bother to get up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alex is walking to the front door. As he reaches it, Roberta appears.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERTA
dialogues.text: Mr. Rada...? Alex turns around

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Yes, Mrs. Della Famina?

dialogues.speaker: ROBERTA
dialogues.text: She used to call me here. If he got on the phone, she would hang up. Susan's a wonderful, sensitive person. Naive in a lot of ways. (beat) I don't know why he goes on like that. in b.g we can make out Della Famina calling out for Roberta.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: (soothing) Do you know where she is?

dialogues.speaker: ROBERTA
dialogues.text: No. She left a telephone number... in case of emergencies. I'll get it for you. HOLD ON Alex. He really feels for this woman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like most of the neighborhood, the Zig Zag bar is changin a thin veneer of gentrification covers the seediness. Hamburgers on English muffins, nine ball at the pool tabl Alex is planted on a stool, waxing philosophic with MAX, of the locals. STASH, the bartender, sports an earring and military bere He pours cheap vodka into a shot glass. Alex downs it; he's already had a few.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: An expression not unlike the one in the previous scene wi Roberta -- except now Alex is feeling sorry for EhimselfR

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: It's a great place.

dialogues.speaker: STASH
dialogues.text: I like New York -- you know where you are.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: -- Nobody hears about Burma much any more -- that's why it's so good. Okay, maybe they got bugs there, ya know, those kind of cockroaches that're as big as shoes...Hey, but nothing's perfect.

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: You don't need no Burma for that. You come to my place, I'll show you some mother roaches humpin' my sneakers. Laughter.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Yeah, but here's the thing, see. (motions with his hands) In Burma, you can be yourself... nobody bothers you. There's nothing to...join.

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: Alex, you've never even been to Burma, what are you talkin' about?

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: That's not the point, Max, is it? I could do pretty well there on what I get. (beat) ...and the women, beautiful women in Burma.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WE SHOOT FROM ACROSS THE STREET. Katharine Raines steps o the doorway of Alex's building. Hands in the pockets of h coat, she watches people walk up and down the avenue. A double-take. Katharine spots Victor panhandling on the corner. She moves toward him, asks him something. Victor points toward the neon sign of the 'Zig Zag' bar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alex still holding forth.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: ...what -- the last five, ten years maybe? People are scared, but the thing is, they don't know what they're scared of. It's definitely something, but nobody knows exactly what...and I'm just not talking EhereR, I mean all over...you know?

dialogues.speaker: STASH
dialogues.text: It's that ozone thing over the South Pole that gets me...sucking out all the oxygen or something ---

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: (overlapping) --- No, no, the weird shit. You know, that people say isn't true, but really is -- That the government's holding back on? Like aliens doing medical experiments on people in their spaceships. (beat) It all started with the Warren Commission. Katharine enters. She is backlit by the sunlight from the door. They all look toward her. She moves toward Alex.

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: The ever popular Mr. Rada.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Class out for the day, professor?

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: Well, let's see -- there were several phone calls. Then I tried what you facetiously refer to as your office. Mr. Rada, aren't you supposed to be working for me? Stash now busies himself at the bar. Max quietly sips his drink. Party's over. Katharine looks to her wrist to check the time. Realizes she's not wearing a watch. She's flustered by this.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: It's three-thirty -- You in a hurry? Look, don't you believe in taking breaks?

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: Breaks are fine, Mr. Rada. It's the binges I object to.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: (past Katharine-- to Max and Stash) I'm telling you...Burma.

dialogues.speaker: A TABLE IN THE CORNER
dialogues.text: Katharine is studying Alex, not quite sure she's got his Alex, sobering up, nurses a club soda.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: It seems to me, we've got a pretty good deal going here. I pretend I'm working and you pretend you're telling me the truth.

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: I haven't told you the truth?

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Oh, c'mon, lady, don't take me for a complete idiot. Susan Blake's not your assistant, she's in the damn art school for Chris' sake. I spent six years in the New York City police department, I think I can handle the mystery of the professor's assistant -- But I tell you what; I bet if you really looked hard you could find somebody even stupider than me not to find Susan Blake.

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: I didn't realize you were so sensitive. (hand under her chin) Low self-esteem, Mr. Rada?

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Just cut the crap, and don't analyze me, okay? We'll call it a day, all right? -- I prefer cash. (beat) You really like living on the edge. We HEAR the SINGING of 'Happy Birthday' from a table in t rear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Katharine looks up, glances over. Alex turns around. A group of FOUR YOUNG WOMAN, perhaps tourists, eating and celebrating a birthday. The kitchen doors swing open. A man with fire in his eyes rushes out waving a meat cleaver, locates the source of t commotion. The man is clearly the COOK. He wipes the clea against his stained apron, then, with a LOUD THWACK, buri deep in the wooden table.

dialogues.speaker: COOK
dialogues.text: (glowering ominously at these women) Shut -- The -- Fuck -- Up! He leaves the cleaver embedded in the table. Spots Alex a the room.

dialogues.speaker: COOK
dialogues.text: (cool and casual) Hi'ya doin', Alex.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX AND KATHARINE
dialogues.text: Alex averts his eyes, brushes away an imaginary crumb fro table. Then with a pained expression, looks up, nods in acknowledgement.

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: Another friend of yours?

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: We were about to wrap this up, remember? Call it three days. And I'd really prefer cash. Katharine tilts her head. A small, confessional smile.

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: Look Mr. Rada, I EdoR want to find Susan Blake and I did lie to you. I'm sorry. Alex chews on the ice from his club soda, deliberating ov apology.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Well, that's a start, anyway. Our view of Alex and Katharine is obscured by FOUR FIGURE MOVING ACROSS FRAME IN FOREGROUND. They appear as a blur, but these are the four woman from the rear table. A momen later, we HEAR a door SLAM SHUT.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Okay. C'mon, lets go.

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: Go? Where?

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: I have to do some shopping.

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: You're joking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bags of groceries on the counter. Alex is putting away a ending series of canned goods on a shelf. Cans, cans, and cans. Katharine watches -- amused and astonished.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: (not facing her) Look, professor, I like things simple. No hassles. I do a little process serving from time to time, find a few runaways -- I get by. I'd just like to keep it that way. (reaches into a bag; rummages for more cans) Someone bashed into my Hertz one-day special while I was running down the relatives that you told me Susan Blake didn't have. As far as I'm concerned, that's not a terrific omen. (beat) And it also strikes me that this job is not hassle-free.

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: As far as Susan having relatives, I honestly had no idea. And the accident with the car...well, that can't have anything to do with me EorR Susan Blake. Katharine reaches into one of the grocery bags, hands Ale couple of the cans.

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: (stressing his first name) Look, Alex... (hesitates) You know that I'm working for the Lynch campaign?

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: (sardonic) I'm not a private detective for nothing. I've seen your picture with her in The Post.

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: Susan was a wonderful artist. I brought her to a couple of campaign functions, asked her to do some sketches. She KATHARINE (cont'd.) was going to paint a few canvases that I'd give to Delaney after the election -- as a present, for her Washington office. It does sound kind of ridiculous now, but I just thought it prudent that I separate...that no matter how tangential, your investigation shouldn't involve the campaign. So I simply told you she was my grad assistant. (beat) It wasn't that far from the truth. Alex takes a can from her hand, shakes his head in a gest of resignation.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Never play poker with a guy named Doc, professor.

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: Does that mean I'm forgiven?

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: It means I hope I can walk away from the table with some spare change.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alex, screwdriver in hand, labors over his answering mach The cover and a few parts on his desk, he peers into the of the mechanism, not really sure what he's looking at. Presses one button. Presses another. Nothing seems to hap The screwdriver slips. A piece of the machine flies out. Rolls about the floor. On hands and knees after it.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Shi -- it! On his desk, the phone rings. He's slightly surprised by Gets up to answer.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Alex Rada. (pause) Hey, Lysenko!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LYSENKO, the man on the phone, pours over some blueprints and checks a page in a book for Alex at the same time.

dialogues.speaker: LYSENKO
dialogues.text: Got a pencil?

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: You got something for me? ...yeah, hold on. Alex cradles the phone under his chin, rummages around fo a pencil and paper.

dialogues.speaker: LYSENKO
dialogues.text: Alex, why don't you just subscribe to the reverse directory, it'd make my life a hell of a lot easier.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Things are a little slow late... (starts writing) Yeah...yeah, I got it...An apartment number? Okay, good...Bridging equip- ment. Yeah, I know it's tough...I appreciate it. (beat) Hey, Lyensko, what do you know about answering machines? (pause) ...Hello?...Hello?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From the hallway decor, we can see this is not a modern building. Alex waits a moment for the elevator. He steps inside, presses the button for his floor-- We HEAR the WHIRRING of an old elevator as it ascends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alex walks down the same hallway as did Katharine Raines the prior scene. He reaches the same doorway. Rings the bell. Waits. No one answers. Alex checks the hall, reaches into the his back pocket fo set of picks. He jimmies the bottom lock. The top lock appears tougher. He bends to have a look at it, while tur ing the doorknob. Surprisingly, it opens -- and Alex is caught momentarily frozen in position. Pleased with himse he straightens up and enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alex switches on the light, takes in the room -- as neat and well kept as before. A grimace on Alex's face; he recognizes a distinct odor.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Not hassle free at all. He glances around looking for something. The living room decorated, not furnished. One wall is completely covered with pale blue drapery -- blues and whites everywhere, a feeling of the first frost. Alex moves cautiously toward an archway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Searches around, finds a dish towel in an overhead cabine CAMERA FOLLOWS him back through the archway.

dialogues.speaker: THE LIVING ROOM
dialogues.text: as he moves tentatively toward a passage way at the oppos end of the room. He now covers his face with the towel.

dialogues.speaker: THROUGH THE PASSAGE WAY
dialogues.text: slowly toward another room. This hallway is dark, but the light ahead.

dialogues.speaker: THE BEDROOM
dialogues.text: Still moving with him now.

dialogues.speaker: THE WALLS OF THIS ROOM ARE SPLATTERED WITH BLOOD
dialogues.text: Alex (CAMERA) lowers his eyes to the bed, approaches it. Flecks of blood on that too. It blocks our view of what l beyond. All we can see protruding past the bed is AN ARM, the carpet next to it drenched red.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: The towel to his face, faint protection from the stench o death.

dialogues.speaker: THE ROOM
dialogues.text: It is AWASH IN BLOOD. Hard to believe this mayhem is from one person. Alex is standing over a body now. OUR VIEW IS BLOCKED by bed. He gazes down. An horrific sight. He Gags. Going to be sick. Turns toward a set of wood and glass doors half hidden by sheer curtains. Pushes through them.

dialogues.speaker: A TERRACE
dialogues.text: Outside in the night air, Alex grips the brick railing, b in deeply. Head down, eyes shut, he hesitates -- wretches side.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Je -- sus! (quietly) Jesus. A few moments. He looks up, gazes out over the terrace. The sky is filled with colored light, flashing neon: Alex looking out over TIMES SQUARE. Pulsating signs, movie mar the traffic below -- all assaulting him in one visual str He takes it in, WE HOLD.

dialogues.speaker: THE BEDROOM
dialogues.text: Alex removes the cover from the double bed, strips the sh He stands over the body, drapes the sheet over it gently, as though he were putting a child to sleep. Kneeling now, he pulls back the sheet to reveal just the and neck of the corpse. WE SEE IT FOR THE FIRST TIME. The is battered and cut, but we clearly recognize the delicat beautiful woman from the yearbook picture -- Susan Blake. Alex, now more dispassionate, examines the face: contusio fresh blood around the left nostril, a wound to the laryn and what appears to be a peculiar purplish scratch mark o the neck. He looks at it closely, runs his finger over th scratch -- almost a caress. He covers the face again, stands over her for a moment. A thin channel of blood seeps through the sheet, as though Susan Blake had been slit open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alex has the dish towel wrapped around his hand like a gl He goes through boxes on a shelf in the closet. At a chest of drawers now, he goes through that. Opens a drawer in a small night table: a few pens, a picture of Susan Blake with Roberta Della Famina and THREE TWENTY DO BILLS. Alex holds the picture in his hand, pockets it alo with the money. About finished with this room, Alex starts toward the doo Stops. A gesture of, "Oh, what the hell" as he moves back to the night table, replaces the money.

dialogues.speaker: BATHROOM
dialogues.text: Looking through the medicine chest, etc.

dialogues.speaker: LIVING ROOM
dialogues.text: At a mahogany desk. Rifles through the drawers. Stops to read some papers. Nothing of interest. He looks around Has he missed anything? Scans the room again to make sure Moves to the drapes, peeks around them -- another set of doors to the terrace.

dialogues.speaker: OUTSIDE ON THE TERRACE
dialogues.text: A few yards from where he was before. A small wrought iro table and chairs. Two coffee cups and saucers on the tabl next to one of them is a watch. Alex stares at it, picks up for a closer look. It is an elegant woman's watch with braided gold band. Alex tosses it around in his hand, fli it lightly in the air. We HEAR the SOUND OF SIRENS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The SOUNDS of SIRENS continue. They come from a squad car and E.M.S. ambulance in front of the building. Another squad car SCREECHES to a halt. FLASHING RED LIGHTS. MORE BLARING SIRENS in the distance. Alex stands next to a phone booth across the street. Move to a trash can nearby, tosses in the dish towel. The emergency services team enters the building wheeling stretcher. For a long moment, Alex watches -- the flashin red lights revealing the anguish on his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elegant. Katharine, Delaney Lynch and HAL RENNERT - Delan campaign manager - sit on sofas surrounding a great glass coffee table. Hal's ASSISTANT leans on the edge of a sofa while Frank Willis paces the room. They're all drinking a Madeira, or Casa Brunella. Somethi red, anyway. All except Delaney. Katharine about to pour Delaney a glass of the wine. Dela places her hand over the empty glass. Doesn't want any. Instead, she pours ice water into a tumbler from a pitche a tray. Drinks that.

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: The point is we have to counter it. We're outspending them three to one and it looks like we're buying it.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Well, the Federal Election Commission's not going to bring an indictment -- but what the hell, a leak of the investigation is plenty.

dialogues.speaker: DELANEY
dialogues.text: The F.E.C. is claiming what?...that it's not my money, but Alfred's?

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: That's about where it stands, yeah.

dialogues.speaker: DELANEY
dialogues.text: Just technical crap, I can spend what I want on the campaign, after all it's EourR money. We can make it a freedom of speech issue.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: (shaking his head) It's a non-starter. People can't grab hold of it. They don't see that without the money you can't reach them. They can't see that as a right. They see a price tag -- period... We're up eleven points, we don't need to take it head on.

dialogues.speaker: ASSISTANT
dialogues.text: It was fourteen last week. A brief and slightly awkward silence -- no one's asked hi

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: (to Hal) How far along are we on the community center spots?

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: They're in post now.

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: Well let's move on them. Air them as soon as we can.

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: How are we handling the investigation?

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: (to Delaney) Frank can say it's politically motivated and there is no violation. (to Hal) And let's use the family issue; there is no distinction between Alfred's and Delaney's money...a tight knit family. It gives us some mileage from Veress's divorce.

dialogues.speaker: DELANEY
dialogues.text: Well, shit, nobody's going to tell me I can't spend my own damn money on the campaign. (pours more ice water from the pitcher) Maybe I can get Pamela Veress to endorse me. Some laughter.

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: We need to rush those spots -- shirt sleeves, people's aspirations, that sort of thing. Put some noise in the channel...drown them out. The telephone rings. Katharine picks it up as the politic conversation continues.

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: Hello?...Yes. (a long pause) Hold on, I'll take it in the other room. (to the group) Be right back.

dialogues.speaker: AN ALCOVE
dialogues.text: Katharine is on the phone, listening in stunned silence.

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: (after a long pause) Yes. I'm here...No, I have guests. I'd better meet you...No, not downstairs. (another pause) Somewhere near here...I can't get away for at least an hour...Where? ...All right, wait for me.

dialogues.speaker: LIVING ROOM
dialogues.text: Katharine enters. The conversation still going on. Frank Willis glances up.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: You okay? Her body language says no, but her reply to the group is controlled, almost casual:

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: Fine. Let's get back to it. Eye contact and unspoken words between Katharine and Fran

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A mini-park and fountain in front of the PLAZA HOTEL. Ale a stone bench staring into the fountain. He turns, sees Katharine walking toward him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as he watches Katharine move slowly from the shadows of t avenue into the reflected light of the plaza.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looking up at her. Eyes empty.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Hello, Katharine. Katharine sits, eyes fixed straight ahead. A long moment.

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: I want to hear about it.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: There isn't much to tell. (pause) She was killed. Susan was murdered. I found her...and then I covered her and called the police. Tears welling up, Katharine looks away, not wanting Alex

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: Was she assaulted?

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: How was she...? Alex doesn't respond. Katharine is up, circling, arms wra around herself. Her head snaps up, glares at Alex. She wa to know.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: (reluctantly) She was beaten up pretty badly. There was some sort of puncture wound. Some- one...she was...slashed... (losing eye contact) ...slashed up. He now looks to Katharine, moves to comfort her, not sure how, or even if he should. Alex holds her awkwardly. Katharine really not letting go. Crying quietly.

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: (after a moment) Just some damned crazy. G0d damned crazy.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Maybe someone she knew. No one broke in anyway. An apartment, over near Times Square. Katharine stiffens, pulls back.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: What's the matter?

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: Nothing! She holds up her hands. Pushing against an invisible wall She backs away.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Hey.

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: (her voice flat now) Alex, thank you. But right now, I just want to think for a while. Can I call you in the morning?

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Maybe you could use a drink. And you know me and the phones.

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: I'd like to walk a little...by myself.

dialogues.speaker: TRAVELLING
dialogues.text: with Katharine moving down Fifth Avenue. Alex catches up, falls in step beside her.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: I think we'd better talk a little more.

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: Tomorrow. Walking in silence. Alex angles toward the window display Van Cleef & Arpels -- rings, diamond necklaces, etc. Katharine continues on a few yards. Stops. What's he up t now? She steps over to the window.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: (fixed on the display) ...How do you suppose Susan Blake rated that apartment? It had to cost plenty, and her uncle sure as hell wouldn't foot the bill, even if he could afford it. No response from Katharine.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: (nodding toward the jewelry display) Beautiful, aren't they? Expensive stuff.

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: (preoccupied) Very. Still peering into the window, Alex reaches into his pock He looks to Katharine, hands her the watch with the braid gold band from Susan Blake's apartment.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: I found your watch. Katharine turns white. She's caught. Looks to the watch,

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: (quietly) How did you know?

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: You lost a watch, I found a watch -- I took a shot. It seems we've both been to Susan Blake's apartment recently. (beat) ...How about that talk, now?

dialogues.speaker: A SMALL TABLE
dialogues.text: Alex is clearly out of his element here. He looks around a waiter, none in sight. Katharine motions with her finge A WAITER appears.

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: Dewers, rocks.

dialogues.speaker: WAITER
dialogues.text: (to Katharine) And the gentleman?

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: The gentleman will have the same. Waiter moves off.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Above 14th Street, they don't know I exist. A tight smile from Katharine. Silence. Finally:

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: You think I killed her.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: It crossed my mind. (beat) No. I don't think you did...that kind of murder, it's too grisly. Women don't commit those kinds of crimes... (his finger tapping his chest) ...We do.

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: Saved by male chauvinism.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Look, Katharine -- The waiter comes to table, serves the drinks, leaves.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: -- Look, we're both in deep shit here. Now, you've got to level with me. I walked out of that apartment with evidence from a homicide investigation -- (louder) -- not to mention things like disturbing a crime scene, leaving a crime scene -- cleaning up the damn crime scene like I'm the men's room attendant at the Hotel Dixie. They take your license away for that, just for starters. Alex looks around, realizes he's shouting. He leans into Katharine, speaks softly.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: You felt comfortable enough in that apartment to take off that gold watch. I want to know what this is all about. Katharine places her hand on top of Alex's.

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: Rada, I'm very scared.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: (as Alex removes her hand) Join the club. I do missing persons. This is murder, the police do murder. Now lay it out for me. Someone was Efucking murderedR here, you understand?

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: (angry now) Of course, I understand. Susan was very close to me. And I don't know who murdered her. There's no reason in the world why anyone would want to murder her. Do EyouR understand?

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Then let's just go to the police. Downs his drink.

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: No. The election is three weeks away, I won't jeopardize the campaign.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Either you tell me a good story or I'm going to talk to the cops.

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: All right. I'll pay you twenty-five thousand dollars to find out who killed Susan, good enough?

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: (without missing a beat) Where did Susan Blake get the money for the apartment?

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: I gave it to her.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: You did? Why?

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: She needed it.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: What are you, the Rockefeller Foundation? Katharine, you think you can buy me?

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: Yes. I do, Alex.

dialogues.speaker: THE BAR AREA
dialogues.text: A flurry of excitement. People are greeting a well tailor man accompanied by a small entourage. It is Alfred Lynch. beautiful yellow and blue macaw is perched on his shoulde Alfred, in an imperial manner, only manages to acknowledg a few of those looking to him. The bird flutters its wing nervously. Alfred notices Katharine at her table, sweeps the bird on outstretched fingers. Tries to hand it to one of his reti blond man in a dark suit. We recognize him as Jimmy Doyle chauffeur we've seen before, although now he appears more bodyguard. Doyle tilts his head away from the bird, more out of loat than fear. Alfred smirks at him, places the bird back on shoulder, strides over to Katharine.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED
dialogues.text: (taking no notice of Alex) Hello, Katharine. Katharine is clearly uncomfortable. A forced pleasantness

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: Alfred. (gestures toward Alex) I don't think you know Alex. Alex Rada, Alfred Lynch. Alex stands, extends his hand. As he does, the bird flaps wings, lunges toward Alex.

dialogues.speaker: BIRD'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Awk! Sleaze bucket! Alfred Lynch laughs, perfunctorily shakes Alex's hand as quickly looks him over. From his manner, it's clear he agrees with the bird.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED
dialogues.text: I'm afraid Griffin likes very few people, Mr. Rada. (to Katharine) How'd your meeting go?

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: Fine. I don't think there'll be a problem.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED
dialogues.text: Splendid. Splendid. Delaney's flying up to Syracuse tomorrow. Leaving me to guard the fort.

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: Association for a Better New York.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED
dialogues.text: Preaching to the converted. We'll see you at the house Thursday, of course.

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: Yes. He smiles at Katharine, then looks to Alex unenthusiastic

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED
dialogues.text: Nice to have met you, Mr. Rada. Alfred moves off before Alex has a chance to reply.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: (almost to himself) Same here. Katharine watches Alfred Lynch, makes sure he's out of si She turns to Alex.

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: Well?

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: (mimicking Alfred) Splendid. Splendid fellow.

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: (annoyed) The money. Will you do it? (more controlled) I believe you said you prefer cash?

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Look, if I'm going to put my ass on the line, I want to know why. I think Susan Blake knew whoever killed her. That puts me out there running inter- ference -- against the cops, against a murderer... (fixing on Katharine) If I wind up like Susan, what the hell is the money? Katharine -- a long pause. Then quietly, deliberately:

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: I want to know who killed Susan, I need to know that. (beat) Alex, Susan and I...we had a special relationship. We cared very deeply for one another. Doesn't come as a complete surprise. Alex rubs his nose, reflecting on this.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: And you don't want anyone to find out, especially before the election.

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: If it was a mistake, I was the one who made it. No one else should have to pay for that. I believe in Delaney Lynch, what she's capable of doing -- a lot of good for a lot of people. If it were to come out in the middle of the campaign that I was having an affair with... (looking at Alex dead on) ...with a girl who was murdered... KATHARINE (cont'd.) Delaney would be tarred with the same brush. Alex, she doesn't deserve that. Silence. Then, a tapping sound. Alex's fingers on the tab Finally stops. Okay, she's made her point.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: ...What about the apartment? Anything there the police can tie to you?

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: I don't think so, no.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: There's something else. You said you hadn't seen Susan in a week?

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: That's right.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: At the the Zig Zag, you were surprised you didn't have your watch...You must have left it in Susan's apartment in the last day or two.

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: I was in the apartment yesterday. Susan hadn't been there.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Are you sure?

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: Of course.

dialogues.speaker: A NEW YORK CITY BUS MOVES INTO FRAME
dialogues.text: Alex gets off, squints as the bright sunlight hits his fa He carries a shopping bag and an arm full of groceries. He notices Victor in his usual spot, motions to him as he up the a grocery bag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alex is cooking something in the kitchen area -- maybe ch Stirs a pot of something while breaking up pieces of chop meat in a frying pan.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX AND VICTOR AT THE TABLE
dialogues.text: Victor eats the chili, ritualizing the procedure as if he at George Plimpton's for a dinner party. Alex is observin this with a gentle scowl.

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: Could I a have napkin, please? Alex raises an eyebrow, slowly gets up, throws Victor a wash cloth from the sink. Victor neatly folds it in his l VICTOR (cont'd) And a knife please, Alex. Alex -- his eyes glued to Victor and the chili as he hand him the knife.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Is there something in there you have to cut? No response. Alex sits, continues eating, still watching intricate maneuvers. ALEX (cont'd) (after a moment) You know, you're driving me crazy? You're really annoying me, I hope you realize that.

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: Setting is very important to the enjoyment of coozine, Alex. Alex looks down in his bowl, stirs it as he eats, doesn't say anything.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: (quietly; after a moment) Yeah...and you make me feel guilty, too.

dialogues.speaker: THE KITCHEN TABLE
dialogues.text: A few scraps of food left in two bowls. PULL BACK TO REVEAL ALEX AND VICTOR. The shopping bag is on the table as well as a box labeled, The Easa-Phone Answering System Some cables and tapes are strewn about. Victor reads a small manual. Alex holds the machine above his head. He is unenthusiastically studying the jacks in the back, clearly preoccupied with something else. Alex puts the machine down, rises, slightly exasperated.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: (very deliberate) Victor...you are trained boxer, and I think there is no question that you would have a better shot at installing this than I would.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alex rummaging through cartons. Finds the one he was look for, lifts out a metal box. He sets it on the bed.

dialogues.speaker: THE METAL BOX
dialogues.text: Alex opens it -- a nine millimeter Astra A-90 semi-automa cartridges and a hip holster.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: He stares at it, the muscles of his face tensing as he do

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Victor wanders in, looks to the metal box, then to Alex. Almost a look of reproach from Victor. Alex notices, shru

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: You know what you're doing, Alex?

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Nope. Alex moves to a poster of Frank Lovejoy. Wets two of his fingers like a spitball pitcher, touches the forehead in the picture.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A downtown hang out. Alex is moves through a group of pos and downtown art scene types. Several acknowledge his pre He's been here before. It's NOISY and some sort of rap-reggae-fusion band plays Alex shows the yearbook picture of Susan Blake to some re Shaking of heads. Shrugs. Alex moves to a redheaded WOMAN in her twenties with casc hoop earrings. She smiles in recognition, moves to the beat of the music.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: (holding out the picture) Heard about it?

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: (above the music) In the papers. Awful. Like some gruesome performance piece.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: See her around lately?

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: Don't think so.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Remember any of the people she used to hang around with?

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: I didn't really know her that well.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: How about a guy named Brian? Dark hair, blue eyes...little shorter than me?

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: Brian? (thinking; shrugs) Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Thanks. Alex makes his way through the crowd. MUSIC rises.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alex on the street. He hesitates a moment, moves downtown does, CAMERA SLOWLY MOVES UP, UP -- A GREAT, MAMMOTH CRAN We still HEAR the FUSION RHYTHMS of the Lismar Lounge as move high overhead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quiet. Empty. Alex walks past a Ukrainian Orthodox church. Stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The darkened church. He stares up at it. The spires reach into the night. A SOUND, like an echo of footsteps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alex listens, still looking to the church. He moves on, a toward the stoop of a brownstone. Rests on its stone step He unties his shoe, glances toward the church and beyond, watching for something -- someone in the dark. Nothing there. He waits, reties his shoe, moves off. WE FOLLOW him down the block, around a corner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A lighted avenue, a neon sign -- 'Downtown Beirut.' Alex inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About the same ambience as its namesake -- dank bombed-ou except here a few paintings from local artist decorate th walls. It's relatively quiet, just a few customers. The bartender, TOMMY, serves a customer a drink. Alex sli onto a stool. Bartender spots him.

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: Alex!

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Hey, Tommy-rot.

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: (gesturing) New surroundings.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Last time I saw you, you were working at Madam Rosa's.

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: It closed. Now, I'm slumming. Commies still under the bed?

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: In the closet, Tommy-rot, in the closet.

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: (pointing at Alex) Scotch straight up with a side of water. I never forget a true patriot.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: (lets it slide) No, I'm holding off.

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: Runaway time?

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Not exactly. Murdered girl. Susan Blake. You heard about her?

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: (becoming interested) Yeah, yeah. She used to come in a lot when I first started. Beautiful girl. Very hot.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Ever with anybody?

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: Yeah -- a real dickhead. Thought he was an artist, wanted to put some paintings up -- severe crap.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Know his name?

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: No. A CUSTOMER yells for a drink. TOMMY (cont'd) (to customer) Hold on, okay? I'm talking to a major force here.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: The kid have dark hair?

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: No...uh, bleached chop.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Hey, Tommy, you ever see her come in with any woman?

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: No, I don't think so. Tommy looks to the customer, gestures that he'll be there a minute.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: How about someone named Brian?

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: You mean with Susan Blake? I know Brian over at Siberia. He might have known her. You know him -- ex-roadie, pretty boy -- helps Eric Montaug run the place. (thinking) Susan Blake...I don't know, maybe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PULL BACK TO REVEAL a man wearing it. He makes strange, mechanical movements. We can now see others masked in the heads of different animals, strutting machine-like on a s Others ACTORS, on tiers of scaffolding, turn quickly like huge gears. We are watching a performance piece in the SIBERIA CLUB. This particular piece is a form of Constructivist theatre In bizarre counterpoint, THREE WOMEN, bathed in a baby blue spot on center stage SING old Supreme's numbers a ca

dialogues.speaker: THE ENTRANCE CORRIDOR
dialogues.text: Alex is squinting at the stage, trying to figure out what this is all about. Alex leans into a MAN who acts like a host, looks like a bouncer. Alex whispers something to him. Bouncer checks around the club, points to a table in the back away from the stage.

dialogues.speaker: THE HOUSE TABLE
dialogues.text: A GROUP OF FOUR at the table -- two young women, a dark haired man in his twenties, another man slightly older. Alex stands over the dark haired man.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Brian?

dialogues.speaker: BRIAN
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: I'm Alex Rada. Can I take a few minutes --

dialogues.speaker: BRIAN
dialogues.text: -- And do what, man? Brian looks to one of the women, caresses her neck. They

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: ...And talk to you about Susan Blake.

dialogues.speaker: BRIAN
dialogues.text: (looks up at Alex) ...I know you, right?

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: We've seen each other around.

dialogues.speaker: BRIAN
dialogues.text: You're not a cop, right? Alex nods. He knows this is a lost cause. BRIAN (cont'd) Bye.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: (one more try) Just a couple of minutes. How about later? I'll be by the bar.

dialogues.speaker: BRIAN
dialogues.text: Hey, man, you're not listening. (with a whole lot of emphasis) Fuck Off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alex leans on a car near the corner. Not many people on the streets now. A few stragglers leave the Siberia Club. Alex keeps an eye on the entrance. Brian and the young woman emerge from the club, move arm arm in Alex's direction. They both wear leather jackets. Brian notices Alex.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: (moving off the car) How about now?

dialogues.speaker: BRIAN
dialogues.text: Shit, don't you give up?

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: I'd really like to talk.

dialogues.speaker: BRIAN
dialogues.text: Too fuckin' bad. He starts to move away. Alex grabs his jacket, pulls him in the direction of the corner.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG WOMAN
dialogues.text: (pulling at Alex) Lay off, damnit. Alex -- pushing her away and yanking Brian around the cor into the alley behind Siberia. He slams Brian against a w Young woman bangs her fists against Alex's shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: (to woman) Go home! She backs away. Alex holds Brian by the lapels of his jac raises his fist as if to hit him.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Okay, asshole, let's have a little cooperation.

dialogues.speaker: A PUNCH
dialogues.text: and then another. Both to Alex's stomach. Alex falls to t ground, sprawled on his back, his hip holster exposed.

dialogues.speaker: A KICK
dialogues.text: this time to Alex's rib cage. Alex winces.

dialogues.speaker: BRIAN
dialogues.text: bends down, reaches into the hip holster, snatches Alex's

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brain and the young woman stand over Alex, laughing, taun Brian waves the gun, jumping up and down.

dialogues.speaker: BRIAN
dialogues.text: Fuckin' phony. You're a pussy, piece a shit pushover. Pointing the gun at Alex, both laughing wildly, they back the alley. He takes aim at Alex as he moves away. BRIAN (cont'd) Let's have a little cooperation, asshole. He squeezes off a round. It's SOUND echoes through the al The SHOT HITS in front of Alex. Alex pulls his arms up to face, his knees move toward his stomach in the fetal posi Brian and the young woman move farther down the alley tow a garbage dumpster. They are still facing Alex. BRIAN (cont'd) Fuck you, man. Fuck you. He raises the gun a second time, then --

dialogues.speaker: A PUNCH FROM NOWHERE
dialogues.text: smack on Brian's chin. He goes down on his back, out cold

dialogues.speaker: THE FACE OF A BEDRAGGLED BUM
dialogues.text: Victor standing over Brian, reaches down, picks up the gu The young woman SCREAMS, goes shrieking off into the nigh Alex is up slowly; he slogs toward Victor.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: (holding his side) Victor, you care. Victor smiles. They drag Brian toward a wall, prop him up ALEX (cont'd) (dawning on him) You've been following me all night, haven't you?

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: You're a great detective, Alex. Alex ponders this remark.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: (shaking his head) That's not a compliment. He takes the gun from Victor, places it in his holster. Grabs Brian's face with his hand. Brian looks up, coming out of it.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Okay, juiceman, let's me hear about Susan Blake.

dialogues.speaker: BRIAN
dialogues.text: I hardly knew her. Alex -- squeezing Brian's face. BRIAN (cont'd) Look, I went out with her a couple of times, maybe six months ago.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: So why'd you kill her?

dialogues.speaker: BRIAN
dialogues.text: Fuck it, you're crazy, man. I didn't kill nobody. Sue had other interests; Sue was schizoid -- I can't handle that.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: I still say you killed her.

dialogues.speaker: BRIAN
dialogues.text: Try somebody else.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Convince me.

dialogues.speaker: BRIAN
dialogues.text: I never saw you, right? (beat) She hung around some real Doctor strange. A guy named Jimmy Ice. He had his own car, used to pick her up and they'd take off -- end of story. (wipes away a trickle of blood from his mouth) Now why don't you be a nice piece of shit and leave me alone.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Why Jimmy EIceR?

dialogues.speaker: BRIAN
dialogues.text: I don't know, maybe he's not that friendly.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: What does he look like?

dialogues.speaker: BRIAN
dialogues.text: Aw c'mon. He's pale, I don't know -- thin, blond chopped hair... okay?

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Have you seen him lately?

dialogues.speaker: BRIAN
dialogues.text: No, really. Alex slaps him lightly on the face a few times.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Splendid. You're a splendid fellow. PAN TO THE PAVEMENT in front of them.

dialogues.speaker: A SIMILAR PAVEMENT
dialogues.text: People's feet traipsing over it. A few at first, then many more.

dialogues.speaker: PULL BACK TO REVEAL
dialogues.text: Delaney Lynch greeting morning shift WORKERS at the Carrier plant in Syracuse. A few local NEWS PEOPLE. Hal Rennert and Frank Willis stand at a respectful distance. Lots of: "Hello, I'm Delaney Lynch, running for U.S. Sena "Need your vote", "Good to see you", etc.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hal Rennert near a chain link fence, signals a car outsid

dialogues.speaker: THE PALE VISAGE OF JIMMY DOYLE, THE BLOND CHOPPE
dialogues.text: He spots Hal, starts the car, drives through the gate.

dialogues.speaker: THE CAR
dialogues.text: rolling slowly toward Delaney, Frank and Hal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The car pulls to a stop near a hanger. Jimmy Doyle and Hal Rennert exit from the front, Delaney and Frank from the back. The four move toward a Sessna Citation aircraft. We HEAR SOUND OF THE ENGINES.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Delaney, Frank and Hal have been checking over some notes Jimmy Doyle smokes a cigarette in a seat behind.

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: ...Advance people did okay, don't you think?

dialogues.speaker: DELANEY
dialogues.text: Where do we stand?

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: Got the meeting at your house when we get back. Go over manana.

dialogues.speaker: DELANEY
dialogues.text: Who's there?

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: Garth and his polling people, Katharine too.

dialogues.speaker: DELANEY
dialogues.text: (to Frank) Pretty damned good turnout at the university. Getting younger all the time. (leans her head back on the seat) ...even the professors. Hal Rennert notices Jimmy Doyle holding a disposable ligh under his palm, moving the flame slowly back and forth cl to the skin on his hand. Hal swings around toward him.

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: (to Delaney as he watches Doyle) ...As long as they can vote in this State.

dialogues.speaker: HAL AND DOYLE
dialogues.text: Hal's eyes narrow, fascinated by what Doyle is doing. Doyle looks dead on at Hal. He brings the flame even clos holding it under his hand, searing the skin on the palm.

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: (nodding toward the lighter) What's the trick?

dialogues.speaker: DOYLE
dialogues.text: (glaring) The trick is in not minding. Hal holds on him for a beat, looks away and pretends to g some notes. We see a perceptible shiver.

dialogues.speaker: DELANEY
dialogues.text: (eyes closed now) ...Frank?...How's Katharine doing?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Like all of us, I little tired I guess.

dialogues.speaker: DELANEY
dialogues.text: She's teaching, too.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I think it's just the three hours this semester. Delaney massages her eyes with the fingers of her hands.

dialogues.speaker: DELANEY
dialogues.text: Well, she looks like hell lately. Needs a rest...And there'll be a damn sight more work after the election.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I'm not sure she'll come to Washington. Eyes still closed, she reaches over and pats Frank's hand

dialogues.speaker: DELANEY
dialogues.text: You're never sure of anything, are you Frank? Frank glances over, some anger showing. He's about to say something, thinks better of it. DELANEY (cont'd) She loves the action. Inside the Beltway, ...that's Katharine's natural habitat.

dialogues.speaker: A CRACKING FIRE
dialogues.text: We HEAR VOICES. PULL BACK to take in a white fireplace and the Louis XV girandole mirror above it. A sense of opulence and style -- just as the other rooms of this house must have. CAMERA FINDS Katharine. She is listening to Hal Rennert's voice as he goes through a schedule. Katharine does look bit drawn, certainly not as elegant as in prior scenes.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK WILLIS AND DAVID GARTH
dialogues.text: They are carrying on their own conversation. Behind them, Garth's ASSISTANTS.

dialogues.speaker: HAL RENNERT AND DELANEY LYNCH
dialogues.text: Hal reads off a list, leans in toward Delaney.

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: ...then the luncheon speech, Metro- politan Women in Business at 12:30 -- Photo op with the mayor at 2:30... (turning a page) 4 O'clock -- New York Hospital shift change -- 5:15 Grand Central -- 6 O'clock, subway stop southeast corner of Lex and 68th. (looking up) ...And the formal dinner back here at eight.

dialogues.speaker: DELANEY
dialogues.text: Ah, the contributors...let's not forget the contributors. (to Frank) -- Find out the name of Stu Rudin's new wife; they change so fast I can't keep track.. .And the names of the commissioner's children.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: All of them?

dialogues.speaker: DELANEY
dialogues.text: If they're more than two or three, just get me the oldest.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: You pulling the comparable worth thing in the luncheon speech? Delaney smiles, a derisive edge to it.

dialogues.speaker: DELANEY
