dialogues.text: You've got press there Frank, you don't want me to talk about the issues, do you? The maid, ETTA, wheels in a tray -- glasses, and champagn ice. She is followed by Alfred, the Macaw perched on his shoulder. Delaney strides over, kisses Alfred, looks to the Macaw.

dialogues.speaker: DELANEY
dialogues.text: (nuzzling the bird) ...And how's my little baby? She holds out her arm, the bird perches on it. Alfred gestures to the assembled. Nods toward David Garth

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED
dialogues.text: David's told me about the latest poll figures. (handing glass to Delaney) I don't think it's too premature for a toast. Champagne is poured. Toasts are made. Alfred moves toward the fireplace, throws his glass into it. It SHATTERS. Another glass follows. Others in the group, less flamboyant than Alfred, follow with theirs, perhaps a bit self-consciously. One lone glass does not shatter, bounces off the fireplac brick, clinks about, rolls onto the antique Bessarabian r It's Katharine's glass. She closes and opens her eyes slo goes "Hmph" to herself, looks around as if to say -- "What next?"

dialogues.speaker: DELANEY
dialogues.text: Alfred's view is that the election is over; voting is just the tedious ritual that confirms the polls...He started as a technical analyst -- all those buy and sell signals. (beat) Katharine, I'm going to need you in Washington and I'd like you to be a hundred percent. You look awfully tired.

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: I'm fine, Delaney. Frank approaches, listens to the conversation.

dialogues.speaker: DELANEY
dialogues.text: I don't think so. Why don't go down to the house in Mousteek** for a few weeks, get some rest.

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: (with an edge) It's out of the question, certainly not until after the campaign. A flash of anger from Delaney. She's seldom spoken to in this tone.

dialogues.speaker: DELANEY
dialogues.text: (controlled now; insistent) All right, Katharine, but why don't you call it a night. Katharine realizes she's overstepped. Usually defers to t woman.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: (interceding) I'll take you home, Katie.

dialogues.speaker: DELANEY
dialogues.text: (to Frank) No, I need you here. Delaney moves to phone, picks up the receiver, presses on of the buttons on the unit.

dialogues.speaker: DELANEY
dialogues.text: (into phone) ...Jimmy, would you bring the car out front, I'd like you to take Dr. Raines home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Katharine staring out the window, lost in herself. The buildings of Fifth avenue stream by. Reflected off the front mirror, we can see Jimmy Doyle's eyes fixed on Katharine. The car pulls up to the curb. Doyle gets out, opens the door for Katharine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Katharine emerges from the back, a DOORMAN tips his ca

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY DOYLE
dialogues.text: I'll see you in Miss Raines.

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: (waving him off) That's all right, Jimmy.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: Katharine, in a robe, relaxes on a sofa. Her hair is wet. She sips a drink; a cigarette burns in an ashtray. We HEAR the DOORBELL RING. Looks over with some surprise: Who could that be? Reluctantly she gets up, moves toward the door.

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: Yes...? As she approaches

dialogues.speaker: THE DOOR
dialogues.text: We HEAR MUFFLED SOUNDS and holes rip through the door -- fragments fly about.

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: almost instinctively knows what this assault is. As anoth BULLET tears into the room, she lunges at the floor, crawls behind an overstuffed wing chair. Another muffled sound, another shot from some weapon with a silencer -- all this happening very quickly, nearly instantaneously.

dialogues.speaker: A LAMP
dialogues.text: as a bullet cuts into its shade. It moves the lamp precar onto the edge of the table.

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: behind the protection of the chair. Terror. Rage. Quiet now. The fusillade has stopped. Katharine peers ove chair toward the door, takes in four bullet holes. Slowly starts to get up. The lamp, perched precariously at the end of the table, f to the floor, CRASHES, POPPING THE LIGHT BULB.

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: turns toward it. Startled, she jumps in fear.

dialogues.speaker: A BLACK SCREEN
dialogues.text: We hear A PHONE RING. Alex rolls over in bed, reaches for the phone.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: (not quite awake) ...Sixth pre... (beat) ...What? Oh. Sorry...Yeah? Yeah, okay. Jesus!...all right, just hang on -- I'm on my way now.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: Katharine is kneeling picking up pieces of the broken lamp. Alex joins her, both tossing pieces into a plastic bag.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Go over it again. Anything unusual happen before your meeting?

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: No. But it was all...almost surreal. The meeting. We went over tomorrow's campaign stops, the dinner at the Lynch's...then Alfred comes in with champagne. (beat) The damn glass didn't break, it bothered me. Must have been tired or in a fog or something. Next thing I remember Jimmy dropping me off...

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: The chauffeur. Katharine reaches for a piece of the lamp. Her robe opens gently over her legs. Alex looks at them. Katharine notic casually covers herself.

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: Nothing much in between. I must have been somewhere else. It was strange, he's usually not that polite. Said he would see me in. (staring off; holding a piece of the lamp) Generally a bleak little character -- you know, I don't know if I've ever heard him say anything before. Alex glances at the closed robe. Moves up to watch her fa There is a moment. Alex stands, tosses a piece of glass i the plastic bag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alex approaches the door, runs his fingers over the holes has to reach over his head. They are placed almost neatly

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Looks like someone just wanted to scare the hell out of you.

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: Well, they succeeded.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Someone uses a silencer, chances are they know what they're doing. This guy was aiming for someone like Patrick Ewing, not you.

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: That's very comforting. Rada, what the hell is going on?

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Got any cider vinegar?

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: What?...Yes. For what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alex is pouring milk and cider vinegar in a glass. He hol it up, measuring with his eye. a jar of honey sits on the counter.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: It' an old Ukrainian remedy. Relaxes you. Katharine watches from the entrance way. ALEX (cont'd) How about some rum?

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: Drink a lot of rum in the Ukraine do they?

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Another one of life's inconsistencies. Katharine tries a smile, leaves. Alex carefully measures a spoonful of honey, pours it in, then another. Katharine reappears with the rum, hands it to him.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Thanks. I don't suppose he has blond hair?

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: (pours in the rum) The chauffeur. What's his last name? She's not sure where this is going.

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: He does. Short blond hair. (staring at Alex) His name's Doyle, I think. Why?

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: You think he might have known Susan Blake? Katharine is surprised by the question, looks to Alex wit some suspicion as he stirs the concoction he's made.

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: (annoyed) Not likely, Alex.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: She had boyfriends.

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: I suppose so. Not many, she was careful. Susan wasn't stupid...I can't imagine him.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: (he hands her the drink; walks past her) Susan was a lot of things to a lot of people.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Katharine sits sipping the drink, not liking it. Alex sits across.

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: You think the Lynchs' chauffeur killed Susan? And he got in the building after he let me off to what, kill me, scare me? Why? It doesn't make sense.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: I don't know. (massaging his temples) Susan hung around the clubs with a thin blond kid, thought of himself as an artist. Does this Doyle paint?

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: How would I know?

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Okay. Has he been with them long?

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: A couple of years I guess. Does the driving, also keeps the wrong people from getting too close.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: (nods toward the drink) Finish it up. He stays at the house?

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: As far as I know. He has a room downstairs. They both do. (grimaces, downs the stuff) Jimmy and Etta, the maid.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: (a broad smile) How'd you like to take me to that party?

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: (incredulous) The dinner? You're joking?

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: What's the matter? (sincerely hurt) Thanks. She's touched by his vulnerability, looks at him in a new light. Katharine smiles, rethinks it. Katharine smiles, looks at him in a new light.

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: Hey, Rada, you have a tux?

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: (smiling back) Yeah...at the waiters' union.

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: I have a date you know. And I'm not sure how pleased the Lynchs' will be.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: I'd like to get in there. Can you fix it?

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: We'll see what we can do.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: We can see part of a blanket tucked under Alex's chin. Katharine moves INTO FRAME, kisses him gently on the fore

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alex slowly awakens. He is on the living room couch. Kath stands over him holding a glass of orange juice. She hand it to him.

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: An old Anglo-Saxon remedy. Wakes you up. Alex takes it, sits up. KATHARINE (cont'd) Thanks for staying.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: What time is it?

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: About nine-thirty. I've got to get going.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Maybe I better tag along.

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: No. (gestures toward the door) You did say that was just meant to scare me, right? Right?

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Ninety percent, yeah. Probably scare the hell out of your neighbors when they see it...There is a small chance...

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: I can't lock myself up in here. If someone really wants to... (beat) There's a man's razor in the bathroom, I left it out for you. Just close the door behind you when you leave, they'll be replacing it this afternoon. Katharine moves to a closet, selects a coat, puts it on.

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: (turning toward Alex) You're a decent guy, Rada. Alex glances up, admiring her, wanting to say something.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: What time do I pick you up tonight?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cars double parked on the street. PEOPLE around the entra a few drinking coffee from containers. Alex moves up the steps, through the entrance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A common area -- tiled walls, bulletin boards, benches. C in uniform move about. Alex waits next to a CIVILIAN WORKER behind a desk. She l up.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Detective DeMarko?

dialogues.speaker: CIVILIAN WORKER
dialogues.text: (points) Stairs. Second floor on your right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Activity. MEN and a FEW WOMEN, mostly in plain clothes, a uniforms. Alex makes his way through a maze of desks. Catches someo eye.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Gene DeMarko?

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: The desk in the back, right next to that side room there.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Thanks. WE FOLLOW Alex through the activity to the back. No one at the desk. Alex peeks into the room next to the desk. It's filled with file cabinets. A burly man about fifty with a receding hair line is open and closing drawers. This is DETECTIVE DEMARKO -- shirt sleeves rolled up, mostly business.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Detective DeMarko?

dialogues.speaker: DEMARKO
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: I'm Alex Rada, I called before.

dialogues.speaker: DEMARKO
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah, right. (checking over a file) So what's up?

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: I understand you're assigned the Susan Blake case. DeMarko looks up, quickly studies Alex, places a file on top of the cabinet.

dialogues.speaker: DEMARKO
dialogues.text: (pointing) There's some coffee over there. Why don't you grab a cup?

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: No, I'm fine. Demarko moves out of the room, spots someone, motions sli with his head. Another man in shirtsleeves acknowledges h wanders toward them.

dialogues.speaker: DEMARKO
dialogues.text: Did you know her?

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: No. She, uh, might've been a runaway I was looking for. Thought I'd check with you. Blake her real name?

dialogues.speaker: DEMARKO
dialogues.text: (a hint of disdain) Uh huh. You a P.I.? DETECTIVE SHERMAN joins them. Younger than DeMarko, he's thin, a heavy New Yawk accent.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Yeah. (looking around the room) I knew your brother at the Sixth. We worked senior citizens robbery unit together.

dialogues.speaker: DEMARKO
dialogues.text: Rada, right? I can check that. He's up at the two-four now, got his gold shield. (nodding to Sherman) This is detective Sherman.

dialogues.speaker: SHERMAN
dialogues.text: Hiya doin'. DeMarko folds his arms, sits on the desk.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: You want to check, go ahead.

dialogues.speaker: DEMARKO
dialogues.text: You got shot, right? Sure, Rada. Right. No, I remember. Phil used to talk about you. Got shot in the shoulder or something, some kid.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Leg.

dialogues.speaker: DEMARKO
dialogues.text: What...four years ago? Phil used to have nightmares about it.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Me too.

dialogues.speaker: DEMARKO
dialogues.text: Yeah, well... (realizing, his voice trails off)

dialogues.speaker: SHERMAN
dialogues.text: Tough out there, huh? Missing persons, that's shit work. That broad got cut up excellent.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: That's what I heard. DeMarko throws Sherman a look as if to say, "enough alrea

dialogues.speaker: DEMARKO
dialogues.text: (laughing it off) Motor mouth. Alex looks to DeMarko, then over at Sherman.

dialogues.speaker: SHERMAN
dialogues.text: (glancing at DeMarko, takes the hint) I hear ya. (as he's leaving) Gotta check with crime scene unit, anyway. DeMarko lets out a sigh. Stares at Alex for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: DEMARKO
dialogues.text: So?

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: I'd like to take a look at the D.D. Fives.

dialogues.speaker: DEMARKO
dialogues.text: You're nuts. This is an active in- vestigation, I'm not letting you look at a homicide folder. (pointing a finger at Alex) You got some information, you better let me know, this is a fuckin' hot case; I don't like competition.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Homicide task force still on it with you?

dialogues.speaker: DEMARKO
dialogues.text: For a while, yeah.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Well, you never know, if I came across something in my travels... Demarko sizing him up, focusing on Alex, trying to read h Finally:

dialogues.speaker: DEMARKO
dialogues.text: I'm going for a cup of coffee; I'll be back in five minutes (nods toward file room) And don't look at that folder on top of the cabinet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alex reading through the homicide folder: complaint follo informationals, serology reports, an autopsy. Scanning this information, he slows at the last page of t preliminary autopsy report.

dialogues.speaker: THE LAST PAGE
dialogues.text: At the bottom, It reads:

dialogues.speaker: CAUSE OF DEATH
dialogues.text: Puncture wound of neck with transected internal carotid artery. Massive hemorrhage.

dialogues.speaker: AUTOPSY
dialogues.text: Associate Medical Examiner

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: puzzled by what he's just read.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alex strides down a hallway, into the men's room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alex sees DeMarko moving away from a urinal. DeMarko zips his fly; Alex is washing his hands as DeMarko approaches.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: I don't get it. She dies from a stab wound, something sharp punctures the artery in the neck. She was cut open EafterR she was killed? DeMarko taps the soap container at the sink. Washes his hands. They don't look directly at each other, but use th mirror above the sink to converse.

dialogues.speaker: DEMARKO
dialogues.text: Better than that. There was blood all over the walls of that place, some freak ripped her open and then splashed the shit over the walls. Hands dripping, DeMarko reaches for a paper towel. Wipes hands. Alex is silent. DEMARKO (cont'd) ...At the orifice of the vagina, creamy white material is noted. Always gets me. That's a euphemism. Has a certain ring to it though, don't you think?

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: DEMARKO
dialogues.text: You don't read so good, Rada. (beat) The autopsy. She had intercourse, too. Must have been a hell of a night. Demarko tosses the paper towel in he trash can. As he lea he turns to Alex.

dialogues.speaker: DEMARKO
dialogues.text: It's not like the old days. All I hear about is clearance rates, clearance rates. Lieutenant's got a hard-on for clearance rates. Don't screw me over. You think being an ex-cop makes you family, Rada? (beat) It does...EdistantR family. You got something, you let me here about it, okay? DeMarko exits. Alex shuts off the water tap, stares at hi in the mirror.

dialogues.speaker: A DOORMAN
dialogues.text: He is blowing a WHISTLE, hailing a cab.

dialogues.speaker: PULL BACK TO REVEAL
dialogues.text: Katharine and Alex near the doorman, both dressed to the Taxi pulls up. They get in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Katharine is smiling to herself. Alex notices.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: You all right? No problems, today?

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: I'm fine. (glances at him, then away) Fine, really. The smile is infectious. Alex grins.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: No, come on, really? Turning to him again, looking at his tux.

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: You look...great.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: You expected something different, right?

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: (almost chiding) Alex...?

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Maybe, I'm a little nervous, all those high flyers going to be there.

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: Take it from me, it doesn't make a difference. Like who?

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Like the police commissioner for one. Katharine laughs.

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: (almost haughtily) A very distant object at the purlieu of the galaxy. Alex looks over -- what did she say? KATHARINE (cont'd) (she takes note) In other words, he's lucky he got invited.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Oh. I'll be sure and tell him that. CAB DRIVER turns around.

dialogues.speaker: CAB DRIVER
dialogues.text: Looks pretty lousy here, how 'bout I take Park?

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Yeah, fine. That's okay.

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: Rada, you think you don't fit in anywhere -- in its own way that's arrogant. It gives you license to dislike people like the Lynch's.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: And you.

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: Maybe.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: I fit in...downtown. Downtown, nobody tries -- that's why I like it. I belong with people who don't belong anywhere.

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: That's incredible self-pity.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Why do you have to try to analyze me? This started off really good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bumper to bumper. The cab barely moves through the street choked with traffic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alex stares out his window, Katharine hers. The cab drive HONKS the HORN, breaks the silence as he yells out the wi at the car up ahead.

dialogues.speaker: CAB DRIVER
dialogues.text: Move it! You from Jersey?! (to Alex and Katharine) You can't make money in this. I'd rather park the son of a bitch and get drunk.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: A man after my own heart. Katharine looks over, a disapproving glare.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: (to Katharine) You want to get out and walk?

dialogues.speaker: TRAVELLING
dialogues.text: with Alex and Katharine. They walk in silence, occasional glancing at shop windows. Finally Alex:

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: ...Guess I didn't say it before, but you, uh, look pretty terrific yourself. (beat) Look, I know this isn't easy for you. You have a right to be scared and all...

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: You trying to apologize, Rada? He gestures, palms up. KATHARINE (cont'd) Probably the closest I'll come. I accept. Tough ex-cop huh?

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Naw, I'm not tough at all.

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: What about the ex-cop part?

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: (putting his hands in his pocket) What about it? They continue down the avenue. Alex takes in a deep breat lets it out.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Got into an argument with a robbery suspect. Only he had a weapon...my weapon. He points it in my face and I say to him, it's all right, go ahead, I'll leave you alone. (derisive laugh) I'm telling EhimR, and he's got the gun, which is mine anyway. So he starts to walk away, and I don't know, I guess I'm angry so I jumped him. We wrestle a little and he shoots me -- point blank, in my leg. (beat) They say I almost bled to death. I don't remember. Just kept thinking how come my leg is smoking. Eighteen months of hospitals and physical therapy I don't walk with a gimp. Just retirement pay and a half-hearted commendation. He looks to Katharine. She slips her arm in his, feels his guilt, embarrassment.

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: That's past. Maybe you have to leave it --

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: -- in the purlieu, right?

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: (nodding self-consciously) Yeah...right in the old purlieu.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They turn onto Sutton Place. We see a Federalist style townhouse -- the Lynch's home. As they approach, Alex sees a built in garage, notices two cars: a limousine and a black sedan. Katharine stops him, turns Alex toward her. She brushes o his lapels, adjusts his bow tie.

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: The Lynch's can be a bit overbearing. Don't let it get to you, okay?

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Okay, captain. I'll need to get into the kid's room. Downstairs? About fifteen minutes. You cover for me. She pushes him toward the door, speaks rapidly.

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: Do it before dinner. Please, please don't get caught. Lord, I hope I know what I'm doing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Before dinner cocktails. MOVERS AND SHAKERS, POLITICAL TY SOME of the LITERATI. High fashion. Drinking. Chatter. In b.g. we see Alex and Katharine appear in the foyer. Et takes their coats.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alex is self-conscious as he looks at the assembled. Kath smiles as Delaney Lynch approaches. Delaney moves to Katharine, kisses her, steps back to obs Alex.

dialogues.speaker: DELANEY
dialogues.text: And this is the mysterious new young man.

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: Delaney, this is Alex Rada. Alex, Delaney Lynch.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: How do you do? Delaney shows her best politician's smile. She's really not pleased. The conversation is more like an admonishmen

dialogues.speaker: DELANEY
dialogues.text: We've had to change things a bit, you know. But I see now it's all worth it. (to Katharine) He's charming, Katharine. Delightful. A VOICE from behind them: "Hello, Alex." Alex turns to se Frank Willis, a drink in his hand. He's clearly had more than his limit.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: (surprised) Frank, what are you doing here?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: (glancing at Delaney) I often wonder myself. Delaney -- without missing a beat, smile unwavering.

dialogues.speaker: DELANEY
dialogues.text: Shall we go inside, we're missing the party.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I'd like to talk to my old friend here.

dialogues.speaker: DELANEY
dialogues.text: Well, I think I'll steer Katharine toward the bar.

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: (a nervous laugh) I'm all for that. Delaney takes Katharine's arm, maneuvers her toward the living room. Katharine turns her head toward the two men as she moves, silently mouths something Alex can't make o

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Well, old buck, you stole my date, you know that?. How the hell are you?

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: You and Katharine? (puzzling this out) Seldom get to these kind of affairs, Frank. She does get around, Katharine.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: You're talking about the woman I love. Alex studies Frank, not sure he's serious.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: (flat; non-committal) No kidding. Frank slaps Alex on the back, a drunken gesture. Wraps hi arm around Alex as he leads toward the living room.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: We'll need to fortify ourselves if we're going to greet the glorious gliterati, note the alliteration.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Alex enters, a deadly enemy appears -- the macaw. It is perched in an elaborate mini-habitat, resembling a tropical thicket. It eats some sort of berry, a watchful eye on the proceedings.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Well, that makes the set, the birdie's here, too. A WOMAN walks past Frank. A gentle half-bow as he moves o her way. He jostles Alex in the process, pushes him close the macaw.

dialogues.speaker: THE MACAW
dialogues.text: a fluttering of wings, a COMMOTION. He lunges at Alex.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX AND THE MACAW
dialogues.text: This time he gets him, a beak digging into Alex's neck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alex grabs his neck, crouches away from the bird.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Shit! (raises the back of his hand toward the bird) You dirty...

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: You all right? (quick pull on his drink) Medic! A few of the guests gather around, ask if Alex is okay. Delaney appears. Alfred strides over with Katharine. Katharine looks to Alex as if to say, "Nice going, Rada."

dialogues.speaker: DELANEY
dialogues.text: Mr. Rada, I am sorry. Would you like to have someone take a look at that? Before Alex can respond, Delaney turns toward Alfred.

dialogues.speaker: DELANEY
dialogues.text: Perhaps Griffin would be more comfortable on his perch in the study. Alex is incredulous: The bird would be more comfortable? Alfred Lynch sweeps the macaw onto his arm, caresses it.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: (no one's listening) No, I'm okay, really.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED
dialogues.text: (as he moves off) Exile, I'm afraid, Griffin. Alex looks around, dumbfounded. Finds Frank who wears a shit-eating grin.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: (holds up his glass toward Alex) A question of priorities, old boot. Katharine grabs Alex by the arm, whispers in his ear.

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: Isn't the idea EnotR to draw attention to yourself?

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: (whispers back) You never mentioned you and Frank Willis.

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: I told you I had a date. And who do you think recommended you? Or did you think I got you out of the yellow pages?

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: No. I'm not in the yellow pages.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alfred stands beside the door of the study at the far end of the room. He's waving Alex over.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: (spotting Alfred) What does he want?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Books line the walls. A great oak desk dominates the room the desk, a green tiffany glass lamp which gives the room illumination. The macaw sits on a simple perch.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED
dialogues.text: (pointing to another door) You can clean up in there if you like. There's some alcohol on the shelf. Alfred moves over to the macaw, places his finger in its Alex glances around, crosses to the bathroom door.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Nice little place you have to work in.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED
dialogues.text: (ignoring the compliment) I understand you're a private investi- gator, Mr. Rada. A conversation mostly of blue smoke and mirrors. The two are feeling each other out.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: And how do you understand that?

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED
dialogues.text: We're very close to Katharine. Naturally, we're always interested in her young men.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Does that include Frank Willis?

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED
dialogues.text: Frank? We've known Frank a very long time, Mr. Rada. We really don't know you at all -- don't know the kind of man you are. (beat) Frank, you see, is predictable -- that's the advantage of a press spokesman. They're not paid to think independently, just to repeat what they're told.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Frank used to be a hell of a reporter, you wouldn't want to sell him short.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED
dialogues.text: No, of course not. You knew Frank -- from the old days? The two men stare at each other. A sense that Alfred alre knows the answer to this.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: ...I used to work robbery unit in the village when Frank was a crime reporter. We had mutual interests. He used to write a damn good story...

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED
dialogues.text: -- Writing is the last refuge of a dilettante, Mr. Rada. Frank's come to grips with life's realities, as I'm sure you have.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Meaning? Alfred strokes the macaw's plummage, disregards the quest

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED
dialogues.text: You'd better take care -- (pointing) of that scratch. I have guests to attend to. (as he leaves) About Katharine? Best not to get too involved.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alex dabs at the scratch with a small towel. Stares at himself in the mirror. He's surprised at how classy he ap in the tux. He places the towel next to the sink, saunter WE HOLD. He saunters back in. One more look at himself in mirror. As he adjusts his bow tie:

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: ...Bond. James Bond.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Alex moves across the room, the macaw scrutinizes him; Alex gives the bird a wide berth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Party in b.g. Alex checks to see if anyone is around. Mak his way down a staircase. WE FOLLOW.

dialogues.speaker: DOWNSTAIRS CORRIDOR
dialogues.text: Several doors. He knocks on one, opens it. Looks like the maid's room. Moves to the door across. Taps lightly, peeks in -- biker posters, an unmade bed, a maga or two on the floor (maybe ESoldier of FortuneR or EGuns and AmmoR).

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alex goes through a dresser, scans some books on a shelf, generally examines the artifacts of Doyle's life. He moves to a closet with a sliding door, partially opene pushes it open further. As he does --

dialogues.speaker: A BLACK CAT
dialogues.text: leaps out, scurries past Alex. Scares the hell out of him Alex jumps away, falls back on the bed.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: (soto; shaking his head in disbelief) What is this, Mutual of Omaha's Wild Kingdom? Gets up, again moves to the closet, examines it. Uniforms and casual clothes, leather jacket, boots on the floor. Next to them a metal case and a stack of paint canvases. Alex flips through them: very ugly, severe crap. He opens the case. There are separations for brushes and what appear to be tools.

dialogues.speaker: THE METAL CASE
dialogues.text: Among the tools, several filed and sharpened screwdrivers varying lengths. Alex picks up one of the shorter ones, h it not like a screwdriver, but like an ice pick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Almost a state dining room: Gilt detail, silk drapery, Baccarat stemware. Dinner is in progress. WAITERS serve. Small talk among th guests. Alex and Katharine close to the head of the table where Delaney and Alfred are ensconced. Next to them, Texas Congressman WADE PATTMAN and his WIFE. Frank sits n to a DOWAGER type, a bit farther from the seats of power. They all listen to a OSCAR RUCKELHAUS (a Kissinger clone) expounding on the state of the world.

dialogues.speaker: RUCKELHAUS
dialogues.text: ...Centripital and cetrifugal forces, the great conflict of the 20th century. Nationalism on the one hand, a new world culture on the other -- and the ineluctable upheaval left in its wake. Leans in confidentially, as if he's surrendering a State

dialogues.speaker: RUCKELHAUS
dialogues.text: ...My own view is that is that eventually the fundamentalists will prevail. An end to Christendom -- to Western civilization. (looking around for a concurring opinion) Now, Katharine, I appeal to you, don't you agree?

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: Well, I hardly think we're presiding over the destruction of the world...

dialogues.speaker: WADE PATTMAN
dialogues.text: -- Now, a course not.

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: ...But, instant communication, the instant images of anarchy -- they tend to become a self-fulfilling prophesy. We dominate the world media and we need to channel it in our own interest...Or maybe, at some point, Oscar's scenario actually happens.

dialogues.speaker: RUCKELHAUS
dialogues.text: There, you see, I'm vindicated. Katharine glances over to Alex, sees he's trying to appea interested. Must think these people are from another gala She winks. He winks back.

dialogues.speaker: WADE PATTMAN
dialogues.text: Now, Oscar here's always puttin' these things in those grandiose geo-PO-litical terms. Never ran for county assessor. If he had, he'd think more like Delaney and me. (puts his hand over Delaney's) Concern with the family, yessir...that's the ticket.

dialogues.speaker: DELANEY
dialogues.text: (mimicking him a bit) Wade, I can't think of the last time I did run for assessor.

dialogues.speaker: WADE PATTMAN
dialogues.text: Now darlin' when you get down to Washington, the two of us are goin' to make one hell of a pair. Maybe get those folks in the White House a little (holding up his fingers) tintzy, wintzy bit nervous. We just might put the fear of G0d into those boys before we're done. (to Ruckelhaus) Now, no offense, Oscar. (to Alex) What about you, Mr. Rada?

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: (astounded) I, uh... (beat) ...I think you're looking in the wrong place. (pointing his finger) We've still got to worry about the Communists, see. I haven't heard a word about that. They're all over the place. They're comin' back, it's not over them. No matter what they say the Russians down deep are still Commies. (Katharine squeezes his hand) And I'll tell you what, if J. Edgar Hoover were alive, it wouldn't be happening. A drop dead silence. Wade Pattman finally chimes in.

dialogues.speaker: WADE PATTMAN
dialogues.text: Now, I think Mr. Rada's got something there. I knew old J. Edgar, you know. He was one tough old crow, wouldn't put up with any KAY-rap from the left or right... (beat, turns to Alex) ...But ya see, Alex, when we all wake up to that fine New York sunrise tomorrow...Well, I have the distinct feelin' we're goin' to still need an adversary. Don't matter much who. Iranians. The Chinese. Hell, I never did care too much for daamn French. (Laughter)

dialogues.speaker: DELANEY
dialogues.text: It's not about ideology, it's about power. Looking to Alex, now. More than a blush of condescension.

dialogues.speaker: DELANEY
dialogues.text: Fear is a great motivator, Alex.

dialogues.speaker: RUCKELHAUS
dialogues.text: You are a Republican, Mr. Rada?

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: (bewildered by the attention) Me? I'm not a joiner. Waiters move in, serve a baked Alaska.

dialogues.speaker: WADE PATTMAN
dialogues.text: (about the dessert) Well, look at that! Now isn't that sumptuous.

dialogues.speaker: RUCKELHAUS
dialogues.text: (to Alex) Wouldn't belong to a club that would have you as a member? Ay, Mr. Rada?

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: No. I wouldn't belong to a club that would have any members at all. Peals of laughter.

dialogues.speaker: WADE PATTMAN
dialogues.text: Now remind me to let my speech writers in on that one, Alex. Alex looks around, mystified -- doesn't get the joke. Puts his energy into eating the baked Alaska.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Katharine and Alex step under the canopy of the building, through the entrance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They stand just inside the door, which has been replaced.

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: Why so silent? You were a hit.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: (nods toward the door) Nice job. Katharine closes the door, she a bit tipsy. They regard e other for a moment. Both a bit unsure. Katharine takes Alex's hand, walks with him across the li room, stops by a small side table next to the bedroom. Sh reaches into a glass goblet, lifts out a spent round.

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: (holding out the bullet to Alex) They found it when they replaced the door. Heap big tip, no questions asked. I thought it might be important; you know, find the gun it came from?

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: (flat, going along) Yeah. I'll check into it.

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: You didn't find a gun in Doyle's room?

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: Alex, he didn't do it, did he? He examines the bullet, rolls it around between his finge

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: ...I don't know about you, but I'm a bit loaded. At least they know how to lay on the booze, the Lynchs. Let's talk about it tomorrow. (kisses her on the forehead) Good night. Katharine moves closer, nestles up against him.

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: Why is it I never seem to be able to get a response from you? (kisses Alex on the lips) ...Goodnight... Katharine stays close, touches the button of Alex's shirt lets her fingers linger over them.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: You wouldn't want me to take advantage? She kisses him again. Leisurely allows her mouth to brush against his before pulling back.

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: No...I wouldn't want that. A man in your condition...The advantage is all mine. Katharine pulls at his bow tie, undoes it. Alex takes her his arms. A long embrace. We see the dress slip from Katharine's shoulders.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: The incongruity of sunlight bathing his stubbled face in angelic glow. Alex awakens. Opens and closes his eyes. Turns to look at Katharine next to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alex reaches over, brushes back Katharine's hair. He kiss gently. Gets up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mirrored on three sides. Alex, a towel wrapped around his waist, holds a toothpaste tube. Sticks his tongue out, ex himself in the mirror. Katharine stands by the door in a robe. Arms folded, she' grinning. Enjoys watching him, catching him in that silly act with his tongue. Through the mirror, Alex sees her, smiles back. He also n the side of his neck -- the macaw bite, now a purplish ma against his skin. He touches it, runs his finger along it A quick glance at Katharine, he turns, bolts from the bat

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alex dresses in a rush. Katharine's at a loss.

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: Hey!

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: At the bar in the Plaza. (hopping about as he puts on a sock) -- Doyle hated the damn bird. He holds the bow tie in his hand, not knowing what to do it. Stuffs it in his pocket, then takes it out.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: (hands the bow tie to Katharine) Take care of this, I'll be back, okay? He hurries out.

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: (yelling after him) Rada...?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alex, still in tuxedo shirt and pants, dashes up the step

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Checking a directory on the wall. Alex finds what he's looking for, moves off.

dialogues.speaker: UPSTAIRS CORRIDOR
dialogues.text: We see Alex turn a corner, stride TOWARD CAMERA. He stops in front of an open office door which reads: 'DR. W. MINT

dialogues.speaker: ASSOCIATE MEDICAL EXAMINER.'
dialogues.text: Alex peers into a small office, sees a SHORT BALDING MAN in his late thirties. Long strands of hair from the side are plastered down on top of his head. The office is clut Alex recognizes a kindred spirit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mintz is erasing something from a piece of paper. Alex walks in, smiles, feels sort of at home. Mintz looks up.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Dr. Mintz?

dialogues.speaker: MINTZ
dialogues.text: (pointing to himself) Yes. Mintz, comma, William.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Alex Rada.

dialogues.speaker: MINTZ
dialogues.text: Hello, Alex Rada.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: I'd like to talk to you about an autopsy you performed. Mintz leans back in his chair, waves his arm at a set of cabinets.

dialogues.speaker: MINTZ
dialogues.text: Which one?

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: I don't have a case number. It was recent. A woman. Susan Blake.

dialogues.speaker: MINTZ
dialogues.text: (thinking; nods) That one I remember. Beautiful woman. MINTZ (cont'd.) Bizarre. You do so many, you usually forget. You insurance? Mintz raises his eyebrows, ala Groucho Marx, points to Alex's clothes.

dialogues.speaker: MINTZ
dialogues.text: Formal investigation?

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Sure, why not?

dialogues.speaker: MINTZ
dialogues.text: You guys are doing well these days. (shrugs) Public record.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: I need your help. The forms'll take me forever. Mintz gets up. Gestures for Alex to follow.

dialogues.speaker: MINTZ
dialogues.text: Okay, Rada comma Alex, c'mon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A PATHOLOGIST washing up at a sink. A covered body on a t Mintz looks around, spots a circular drill. Turns it on. eyes bulge -- bewildered horror.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: (nervously) Hey, what, uh...you're not going to...

dialogues.speaker: MINTZ
dialogues.text: (waves him off) No, no, no, relax. Let's go.

dialogues.speaker: THE CORRIDOR
dialogues.text: Alex points to the wound on his neck.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: I think the girl had the same mark.

dialogues.speaker: MINTZ
dialogues.text: I'll check the report. Take a look at the pictures.

dialogues.speaker: MINTZ'S OFFICE
dialogues.text: The autopsy report and photos are spread out on the desk. Alex and Mintz are going over them. Mintz bends down, pulls some files off the top of a tiny refrigerator, looks around for a place to put them. Hands to Alex, who places them on a chair. Bending down again, Mintz opens the refrigerator, finds h a salami. Grabs it and some bread. The WHIRRING of the CIRCULAR DRILL, it slices through the salami. Mintz cuts a few pieces, makes a sandwich.

dialogues.speaker: MINTZ
dialogues.text: Want some?

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: I'll pass. (pointing to photo) See, here -- It's the same kind of bite I have on my neck Mintz eats his sandwich, looks over the autopsy report.

dialogues.speaker: MINTZ
dialogues.text: Okay...

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: It's a bird bite, right? A macaw.

dialogues.speaker: MINTZ
dialogues.text: A bird with a hooked bill wouldn't be inconsistent with the findings -- Maybe a parrot.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: And how long before she died did she get the bite?

dialogues.speaker: MINTZ
dialogues.text: Hard to say, Alex Rada. Within, oh, twenty-four hours of death. Alex paces the small room, thinking.

dialogues.speaker: MINTZ
dialogues.text: (holding out sandwich) Sure you don't want a bite?

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: (waves him off) Look -- could she have been brought to the apartment unconscious, then killed?

dialogues.speaker: MINTZ
dialogues.text: She was definitely killed in the apartment --

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: -- With a sharpened screwdriver, maybe?

dialogues.speaker: MINTZ
dialogues.text: Or an ice pick. See?...Then that extraordinary wound extending to the symphysis pubis. (showing Alex a photo; he tries hard not to look) The contusions didn't cause death. They were administered before, so it wouldn't be inconsistent with the findings.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Is that a yes? She could have been knocked unconscious somewhere else and then killed in the apartment? -- Would that be consistent with the findings?

dialogues.speaker: MINTZ
dialogues.text: If you put it that way -- yes.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: (brightening) Thanks, Doc. (about the sandwich) You know, you should try that with some nice Ukrainian bread.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see Alex exit the florist holding what appears to be a a single flower wrapped in tissue paper. He no longer wears the tuxedo shirt and pants; he is dressed (for Alex anyway) normally.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alex steps off the elevator, moves to Katharine's door. He holds a flower, a single white rose -- the romantic sa He RINGS the BELL.

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: ...Who is it?

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: It's me, Alex. There is a long moment, perhaps muffled sounds from insid Finally, Katharine opens the door. She peers around the d doesn't look that happy to see him. She notices the flowe opens the door all the way to let him in. Guilt written a over her -- a kind of tenderness, too.

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: Come on in, Alex.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: For you. Hands her the flower, waits for a response. She can't mak eye contact.

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: It's beautiful. He moves to kiss her, she turns her head so the kiss is o cheek. Katharine strides off with the flower.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: What's the matter? Lays the rose on a glass coffee table, turns to Alex.

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: ...About last night... He can tell what's coming -- his defense is sarcasm.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Don't bother, I understand. I just work for you.

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: (sharp) -- That's not it -- and that's not fair. (beat, softer) Look, Alex...you wouldn't want me... I'm all confused, mixed up...You know we'd kill each other. All that constant bickering... The bedroom door opens, Frank Willis appears.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Hiya, Alex. Frank looks to Katharine, he feels rotten about this.

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: (annoyed, embarrassed) Frank!

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Might as well get it over with, Katie. (to Alex) Sorry, Alex.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: (staring at Katharine) ...You've been a busy little beaver. She lets the remark slide. Alex stands awkwardly, conscious of his hands, not knowin what to do with them. Slides them into the pockets of his coat.

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: Frank, maybe Alex and I should talk alone?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Sure...Sure, Katie.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: (overlapping) No, no, don't let me interrupt. I'm just leaving. Alex, trying to hide his feelings, moves to the door with kind of swagger. Katharine grabs him. She glances back at Frank, who disappears inside.

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: ...Alex, I like you very much. Very much...It's just that Frank and I...It's comfortable, Alex. He puts up with a lot. I just wasn't really sure...until all this. (a pause) Last night was my...

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: -- Fault? Is that what you're going to say, fault?

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: (stiffening now) No -- I'll tell you what it is, Rada. It's that I'm a sucker for decent guys. Men who never quite push hard enough, men who think they're tough, then let them- selves get ripped apart inside because they really care about something...only they won't admit it, even to themselves. (beat) Decent guys, Rada...like you. A long moment from Alex. He's unforgiving.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: You left out decent young girls. Katharine's eyes narrow -- the hurt is there, but she won strike back.

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: Okay, Alex... (beat) ...Okay.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: And try this one on, lady. Your... EfriendR...Susan Blake?...Alfred Lynch did her, not the Doyle kid.

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: (not certain she's grasped what Alex has just said) What? That's just crazy talk.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Is it? We'll see.

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: Alex, don't do anything stupid.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: You paid me to do a job. Like you said, all I have to do is push a little harder, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cars and buses. The glow from headlights. HONKING of HORN Alex crosses the street toward Central Park. From behind, Frank Willis catches up. They stand in the middle of the avenue as traffic whizzes by.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Look, Alex, it's just the way it is.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Right, Frank. Cars dodging them. Swerving. Honking.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Can we at least talk about this on the sidewalk?

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: I don't give a shit -- you love her?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: About the only thing I care about, old buck. Alex nods, accepts this. He walks across the street. Fran waits for a car to pass, catches up again on the sidewalk opposite.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: ...I want you to know something, Alex. About Katie. I knew...about her affairs -- about the Blake girl. She wanted someone to find her. I helped.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Thanks for the business, Frank.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: You think I'm an A-number-one putz, right? Alex stops, pats Frank on the shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: It's been a long night all around. I'm going to go home. Why don't you go where you have to, Frank. Alex again moves up the block, Frank begins to follow, Alex waves him off.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Alex...

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: (turning toward Frank) ...Really, Frank. Alex turns away. We watch him pad downtown.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quiet. Empty. A wall separates the entrance of the park from the sidewalk. Benches line Fifth Avenue in front of the wall. Alex, disconsolate, is not sitting on a bench, but on top the concrete wall. He stares off at the apartment buildin across the street. WE HOLD ON ALEX.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A squad car SCREECHES INTO FRAME. Another and then anothe POLICE jump out, guns drawn. FLASHLIGHTS spray the darkne Sprawled out on the sidewalk in a drunken stupor is Victo He slowly attempts to get up as two cops approach. He sta toward the brick of the townhouse, tries to prop himself near a window.

dialogues.speaker: THE FRONT DOOR
dialogues.text: Etta looks out on this scene, half hidden by the partiall door.

dialogues.speaker: THE POLICEMEN AND VICTOR
dialogues.text: They help him up. As they do, he pushes them away, spread his arms in a gesture as if to say, "Hey, I'm fine." One hand holding a bottle, Victor thrashes about, knocks a window pane, breaking it.

dialogues.speaker: A SHRIEKING BURGLAR ALARM SOUNDS
dialogues.text: The policemen spin Victor around, grab the bottle, handcu him from behind.

dialogues.speaker: THE FRONT STEPS
dialogues.text: Another patrolman moves toward Etta.

dialogues.speaker: POLICEMAN
dialogues.text: (above the sound) Shut it off! Can you shut it off? Etta disappears. The patrolman waits.

dialogues.speaker: A SQUAD CAR
dialogues.text: Two policemen put Victor in the car, one tucks the back o his head down as he pushes him into the back seat.

dialogues.speaker: THE FRONT STEPS
dialogues.text: The alarm has stopped. A cop talks to Etta.

dialogues.speaker: ETTA
dialogues.text: ...Later. This is the Lynchs'. Mrs. Delaney Lynch and Mr. Alfred Lynch. Nobody's here now, later.

dialogues.speaker: POLICEMAN
dialogues.text: Yes, Ma'am. You be sure to turn that alarm back on now?

dialogues.speaker: ETTA
dialogues.text: Don't you worry about that.

dialogues.speaker: THE SQUAD CARS
dialogues.text: They leave, SIRENS BLARING.

dialogues.speaker: FROM THE SHADOWS
dialogues.text: As the squad cars move out, Alex emerges from near an iro overlooking the river. He sneaks toward another ground fl window. With the sirens still blaring, he breaks the pane It can hardly be heard above the din. He reaches in, unlatches the window lock, boosts himself

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alex moves about, pulls a flashlight from a pocket. In th b.g. there is a faint light coming from the downstairs quarters.

dialogues.speaker: A STAIRCASE
dialogues.text: leading to the upstairs bedrooms. Alex points the flashli toward them.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED LYNCH'S BEDROOM
dialogues.text: Alex inspects the bedroom, looking for some connection be Alfred Lynch and Susan Blake. Finds a gun in the night ta examines it, puts it back.

dialogues.speaker: THE FIRST FLOOR STUDY
dialogues.text: going through the oak desk, filing cabinets, papers on a table. Nothing. Alex sits in the leather chair behind the desk, glances t the open window, thinking. Spots a few newspapers on top desk, leafs through them casually. They are all out of to papers: Utica, Syracuse, Albany -- all have articles abou campaign. A front page picture of Delaney Lynch in the Buffalo Evening News, her staff behind her. Alex notices something -- the long flowing hair of a woman in the background of the photo. He opens a drawer of the desk, then another. Where'd he see it? Finds the magnifyi glass he'd spotted.

dialogues.speaker: NEWSPAPER PHOTO SEEN THROUGH MAGNIFYING GLASS
dialogues.text: Susan Blake is clearly visible near Hal Rennert and Alfre Lynch.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: Alex folds the paper, stuffs it in his jacket. Places the magnifying glass back in the drawer, it makes a sound as closes it. Alex is up now. We HEAR a NOISE coming from the hallway. Instinctively, Alex pulls his gun from the hip holster, u the safety. From outside in the hallway:

dialogues.speaker: ETTA
dialogues.text: ...Mr. Lynch?...Jimmy Doyle, is that you...? Alex lowers the gun down to his side, stands very still. A long moment, then footsteps moving away from the study. Satisfied Etta has gone off, Alex turns toward the window Listening carefully, he hears ANOTHER SOUND, this time fr within the study. Someone else is in this room. Alex shines the flashlight toward the sound. He sees a pair of SMALL BEADY EYES. Alex makes a move to the window bumps his knee on the desk, knocks his gun loose -- THE GUN GOES OFF -- A CHILLING INHUMAN SCREAM next to him. Frantically, Alex points the flashlight toward the floor, grabs his gun. Leaps toward the window.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. SUTTON PLACE
dialogues.text: Alex running down the block, around the corner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alex still running through the streets. Looks behind. No one following. He stops to catch his breath. WE CAN NOW SEE FEATHERS on his jacket, in his hair. He notices t Breathing heavily, he brushes them off. It dawns on him, slight smirk.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Bye, bye, birdie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Delaney and Alfred, both in robes, are up and about. Dela reaches for a bowl, places it on a counter. Alfred sits a the table. They look tired. Etta appears in the entrance to the kitchen, surprised to see the Lynchs.

dialogues.speaker: ETTA
dialogues.text: (moving toward counter) Mrs. Lynch...? I'll do that.

dialogues.speaker: DELANEY
dialogues.text: That's all right, Etta, I'll take care of it this morning.

dialogues.speaker: ETTA
dialogues.text: Yes, Ma'am. Etta exits. Delaney crosses to the refrigerator, retrieve some butter and eggs along with a carton of orange juice.

dialogues.speaker: DELANEY
dialogues.text: Nothing was taken?

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED
dialogues.text: I don't think so.

dialogues.speaker: DELANEY
dialogues.text: Son of a bitch! Why would someone do that? They were looking for something, Alfred. Moves to Alfred, pours him some juice.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED
dialogues.text: What could they find? Don't let this interfere with what we have to do. Delaney crosses back to the counter. Heats a frying pan.

dialogues.speaker: DELANEY
dialogues.text: It was much simpler back when...remember, making you breakfast in the house on Legion Street? (beat; thinking) ...They didn't have to kill Griffin. It was planned. I'm telling you, Alfred, this was planned. Staring off now, Delaney CRACKS THE EGGS against the side the bowl. Lost in thought. A beat.

dialogues.speaker: DELANEY
dialogues.text: ...That detective Katharine's seeing. He thinks he has reason to be susp...

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED
dialogues.text: (interrupts) Perhaps I should have a talk with Mr. Rada. A meeting...to discuss his future. Beating the eggs in the bowl.

dialogues.speaker: DELANEY
dialogues.text: Yes. Yes. And I want Katharine with me in Albany tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: THE FRYING PAN
dialogues.text: Delaney pours in the eggs, the pan sizzles.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Of course, it's really not our affair. It's possible she may not see him again.

dialogues.speaker: THE WOLLMAN ICE RINK
dialogues.text: A man sits on a bench. We MOVE IN CLOSER. It's Alex. He's feeding pigeons from a brown paper bag. He holds a newspa under his arm. SCHOOL CHILDREN parade past, all in the unifrom of some private academy. Alex lingers on the bench, then moves to the railing of the ice rink to watch the skaters. Katharine Raines strides into view, stands next to Alex. doesn't look at her.

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: Thanks, Alex.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Anytime.

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: I still feel as though...

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: -- that's not what you wanted to talk about, is it? She takes a thick envelope from her coat, hands it to Ale

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: No, I brought you something. Alex opens it -- a whole lot of money. He flips through t bills, places the envelope in his pocket.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: (still watching skaters) ...You know, the other night at that dinner party, I had a conversation with Alfred Lynch in his study. I thought he was trying to warn me off you... but it was Susan Blake he was talking about. I was a little slow.

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: I just don't believe it. Let the police handle it.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: (turning toward her) The police? Why the police all of a sudden?

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: Take the money, Alex. It's finished. (beat) Just some freak...some crazy freak; it wasn't Alfred Lynch.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: ...He wouldn't get his hands dirty. (staring at her) You forget what they did to her? It was the Doyle kid, but he did it for Alfred Lynch...for ELynchR. When Doyle used to pick her up downtown, he was driving her to see your friend Alfred. ALEX (cont'd.) (beat) And I've got news for you, Susan Blake wasn't really missing, she was upstate -- with him.

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: (uncertain) How do you know that? I read it in the papers. Alex hands her the paper he carries under his arm -- the copy of the EBuffalo Evening NewsR. Katharine stops, studies the picture, looks to Alex.

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: (still resisting) ...it doesn't prove he had her killed. Why?

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Susan Blake had trouble letting go. Maybe she was going to tell the future Senator, or the papers. Maybe Alfred got nervous...maybe he enjoyed it.

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: ...Let me count the maybe's. You'll need something more than a newspaper picture and speculation about...

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: -- Well, I'll let you know tonight, Alfred wants to see me.

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: (incredulous) What?

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Right. Why would Alfred Lynch want to see me, get some advice on a leveraged buyout, maybe? I'll call you tonight...

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: -- I won't be around tonight, I'm going to Albany with Delaney -- the last Veress debate. I want out, Alex. KATHARINE (cont'd.) I want the investigation finished. (she turns to leave) Just finish it now, okay? Alex grabs her arm, takes out the envelope. He removes a few bills, hands Katharine back the envelope with the res of the money.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: (a wry smile) For expenses. Probably won't be able to use the rest anyway. (serious now) What does that mean, 'you want out?' -- That mean you don't want to know...or that you already know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An eerie glow. The only illumination, the light from the tiffany lamp on the desk. Alex and Alfred sit across the desk from one another, sta not saying a word. Alfred's hands rest under his chin, as if in prayer. Finally:

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED
dialogues.text: You can't seriously believe I had something to do with this woman's death? It's delusional, Mr. Rada.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: I think you were screwing her and you had your boy Doyle kill her...that's what I think. Alfred doesn't react, his eyes betray nothing.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED
dialogues.text: You saw her picture in a newspaper. Lot's of women follow the campaign around, that's hardly an indictment for murder...Do you know I'm astonished by you? You've got balls, all right. Do you actually think you can challenge me? In this town? (beat) I'll tell you this: Nothing is going ALFRED (cont'd.) to stand in the way of my wife's election. You may not comprehend this, Mr. Rada, but I hold your future in my hands. Alfred rises to his feet, moves to the now empty perch of Macaw, swings it slowly back and forth. He faces away fro

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: You wouldn't be threatening me would you, Mr. Lynch?

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED
dialogues.text: (disdainful tone) Not at all, Mr. Rada.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: You know I saw her, after. (beat) Her guts were in a puddle on the floor. Alfred turns toward Alex, just stares at him for a long moment.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Yeah...?

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED
dialogues.text: Someone broke in here last night. Deliberately killed our macaw. It was a vicious, spiteful act.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Maybe the bird had enemies.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED
dialogues.text: Are you trying to be clever, Mr. Rada?

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: (mimicking Alfred's disdainful tone) Not at all, Mr. Lynch. A curl from Alfred's lip, not actually a smile.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED
dialogues.text: You EareR interesting in your own way. Do you know EPolitics Among NationsR? I have it here somewhere. Puts a hand in his pocket, moves to the bookshelf. Looks for the volume. Can't find it.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED
dialogues.text: In any case, it's the same among human beings -- one nation...one person, they're essentially irrelevant. It's power that counts. Power, Mr. Rada, is an elegant principle of universal law, the less you use, the more you accumulate. (beat) And if you EdoR use it and lose, its evanescent nature becomes clear. Alex stares blankly -- is this guy joking? A deep sigh fr Alfred, know he's not quite communicating. Tries the dire tack.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED
dialogues.text: -- What I mean, Mr. Rada, is that if you go up against me, you better be damn sure you can win.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Well, Mr. Lynch, I'm going to give what you said a great deal of consideration. Yes sir...consideration.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED
dialogues.text: (he does laugh -- in disbelief) You are a ballsy son of a bitch. (beat) Know Cargill, Finch and Wells?

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Yeah, I know it. Big time law firm. So? .bp

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED
dialogues.text: They're looking for an investigator, I'll arrange it for you. We'll call it a lesson in power -- it enhances mine and you get a chance to accumulate a little of your own. I'd rather have you on my side of the line, even though, quite frankly, Mr. Rada, (enunciating slowly) you are one very small piece of shit.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: I appreciate the sentiment.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED
dialogues.text: It's your life after all...think about it.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. SUTTON PLACE
dialogues.text: Alex walks along the sidewalk opposite the Lynch townhous Glances back over his shoulder, sees Alfred through the w He's framed by the glow of the tiffany lamp, working on p at his desk. We follow Alex to the corner. Very little activity on Yor Avenue. HEADLIGHTS of a black sedan switch on, the car ro toward Alex, gains speed as it pulls away from the sidewa For a moment, Alex freezes. The car shoots by him. Alex turns, again looks back toward the Lynchs' study. Th light has gone out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alex is on the phone with Detective Demarko.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: ...I might have something for you. You may not like...What? No, don't worry. (beat) ...Hey, DeMarko I need a little favor...C'mon, would I do that? Look, can you check on a drunk and disorderly for me, up at the eleventh? The name is D apostrophe A-M-A-T-O...Victor... It couldn't have been much. If you would... A KNOCK on the door.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: (raised voice toward the door) Yeah, hold on! (into phone) ...Yeah, pals, Demarko. Vagrants are my life, right. Will you check? Thanks, you're a prince...wha... a few days, okay. Right. Hangs up. Rises.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Who is it? From behind the door.

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: It's me, Alex -- Victor. Moves to the kitchen table, picks up a glass decanter of drops with a small ribbon attached. Alex strides toward t door.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: I was just talking about you. (as he opens the door) Got you something...

dialogues.speaker: THE OPEN DOOR
dialogues.text: His eyes bulge, a screwdriver planted in his neck. Victor clutches at it, falls toward Alex.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: stunned, catches him with one hand, still holds the decan the other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holding another sharpened screwdriver, plunges it toward Alex's face. Instinctively, Alex holds up the decanter -- it blocks the weapon. The decanter is shattered, the contents spilling over the floor.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX AND DOYLE
dialogues.text: Doyle lunges at him again, but he slips over the gum drop on the floor. Falls. Sprawled on his back. Alex tries to lay Victor down gently, kicks at Doyle at t same time. Alex catches him square in the face, Doyle wri in pain.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX'S HIP HOLSTER
dialogues.text: He reaches for his gun, pulls it out.

dialogues.speaker: DOYLE
dialogues.text: on the floor, lashes out with the screwdriver, stabs Alex the leg.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: as he screams in pain, "Son of a bitch." Tries to aim the at Doyle.

dialogues.speaker: DOYLE
dialogues.text: scrambles up, runs out the door.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: down on one knee now, holding his leg. Looks to Victor, t him over. Nothing he can do for him anymore. Alex is up, half running, half hobbling out the door, dow stairs.

dialogues.speaker: ON THE AVENUE
dialogues.text: Alex spots Doyle running up the block. Braces himself and points his weapon. People near him scatter. He squints, can't quite see. Too much of a crowd up ahead anyway. Takes off after Doyle, forgetting his leg. We can see the blood drenching through his pant leg.

dialogues.speaker: RUNNING THROUGH THE STREETS
dialogues.text: past street peddlers pushing their wares, past outdoor fruit stands still open -- not getting much closer to Doy Alex sees him turn down a side street.

dialogues.speaker: THE SIDE STREET
dialogues.text: Much quieter, no one about. We HEAR GLASS SHATTERING in the distance. Alex stops, listening for it again. He moves past the Ukrainian church we've seen before, toward a row of tenement buildings.

dialogues.speaker: THE STEPS OF A TENEMENT BUILDING
dialogues.text: Alex peers in toward the entrance -- the inner glass door has been shattered. Not all that unusual in this neighborhood.

dialogues.speaker: TENEMENT BUILDING
dialogues.text: Inside, Alex checks the hall. Gun drawn. He moves cautiou toward the stairs. Climbing up slowly, he feels his leg f the first time, reaches around to touch the back of his p Stares dumbly at his bloodied hand.

dialogues.speaker: THIRD FLOOR LANDING
dialogues.text: Alex hugs the wall, quickly moves out into the light. Poi his gun toward the landing above. No one there.

dialogues.speaker: THE DOOR TO THE ROOF
dialogues.text: Alex on the last set of stairs, pushes through the door.

dialogues.speaker: THE ROOF
dialogues.text: We PAN the roof area -- unused brick smoke stacks, a flat tar-papered surface with no barrier at the roof's edge; no connection to the next tenement building, or to the Ukrainian church on the other side. Alex listens for a sound, can't hear anything but vague traffic noises below -- maybe Doyle is not here. Alex turns to leave, opens the roof door. As he does, fro above the roof door --

dialogues.speaker: AN ARM
dialogues.text: slashes out, rips through Alex's jacket.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: clenches the arm, rips Doyle down from above the door.

dialogues.speaker: DOYLE
dialogues.text: on his back, a gun pointed in his face. We HEAR a CLICK as the A-90 is cocked.

dialogues.speaker: THE EDGE OF THE ROOF
dialogues.text: Alex holds Doyle by his hair, the gun is pointed not at Doyle's head, but pressed against his crouch.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: (pulling hard on Doyle's hair) Tell me what I want to hear, you fuckin' little cum stain or -- You - Are - Dead.

dialogues.speaker: DOYLE
dialogues.text: You want to know if I killed the bitch, too? Yeah. You think I'm afraid of dying, man? Not like your friend. Pissed in his pants. (beat; taunting Alex) It was my idea to rip her open -- And the blood all over the walls, too... (almost an ecstasy) ...It was majestic. Alex pulls Doyle's hair tighter, holds him over the edge the roof -- we can see the church steps, the street far below.

dialogues.speaker: DOYLE
dialogues.text: (contemptuous, challenging Alex) I fucked her, Rada...after. Alex. Losing it. Shouting now.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Why did you bring her back to that apartment!?

dialogues.speaker: DOYLE
dialogues.text: I do what I want, I do what I'm told. Fu -- cking majestic.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: By Lynch? Alfred Lynch told you!? Doyle spits at Alex, shakes his head loose from Alex's gr Spreads his arms out as if to fly. Pushes off the roof. As he falls backward toward the street below:

dialogues.speaker: DOYLE
dialogues.text: (laughing and yelling as he plummets) Yeah! Lynch! Fuck you! Alex leans over the edge, watching him fall. We can make out a figure walking down the church steps.

dialogues.speaker: THE CHURCH STEPS
dialogues.text: The figure is Father Stefanyk. He glances up as Doyle cra onto the church steps next to him, landing with arms out- stretched in the shape of a cross. Father Stefanyk looks to the body, toward the sky, toward the body again. He kn crosses himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lots of activity. Demarko has a folder open. Alex is next to him

dialogues.speaker: DEMARKO
dialogues.text: Forget it.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: She was knocked unconscious and then brought back to that apartment -- EthenR she was killed.

dialogues.speaker: DEMARKO
dialogues.text: You got something that isn't old news?

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Why did Doyle go to all the trouble to bring her up there? He could have did her and dumped the body anywhere.

dialogues.speaker: DEMARKO
dialogues.text: What the hell does this have to do with Alfred Lynch?

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Susan Blake had a lover, a lover that paid for that place -- maybe Lynch didn't know who it was, but he was going to lay it on whoever was keeping her...and he was going to leave it to you to find out who. Then I came along and screwed things up for him.

dialogues.speaker: DEMARKO
dialogues.text: In the first place, Susan Blake paid for that place every month, with her own checks.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Yeah, so where did she get the money?

dialogues.speaker: DEMARKO
dialogues.text: ...Maybe she earned it. Look, Rada, you don't really think I'm going to arrest Alfred Lynch -- EAlfred Lynch yetR, on some cockamamie theory about a lover and why the Doyle kid does the girl in her own apartment? The Doyle kid was a freak show -- he was into whaddaya call it, uh, performance artwork -- that's why he does her there with all the blood...like a ritual, see?

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Doyle admitted it was Alfred Lynch. DeMarko shakes his head, grimaces. Speaks to Alex as thou were incapable of comprehension.

dialogues.speaker: DEMARKO
dialogues.text: Do you know if I arrested Alfred Lynch on the basis of what you've been saying they'd have my shield. EAt bestR, DEMARKO (cont'd.) I'd be doing dispatch duty at the borough, answering phones -- giving out log numbers all day. I don't want to do that. Alex leans on the desk, grabs a pencil from several in a starts tapping the pencil on the desktop as he listens.

dialogues.speaker: DEMARKO
dialogues.text: Now, this case is closed. The lieutenant says it's closed, the assistant chief says it's closed and I say it's closed, okay?

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Okay, DeMarko, but let me guess? Nothing to the press until EafterR the election, right?

dialogues.speaker: DEMARKO
dialogues.text: (defensive) That's the way it's coming down, yeah. There are some loose ends, some paper work, sure -- so?

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Right. After the election.

dialogues.speaker: DEMARKO
dialogues.text: Rada, what are you knocking your head against? It doesn't work. And where the hell is this so called lover -- you got absolutely nothing. Alex looks to Demarko, realizes he's right. Sticks the pe back in the mug, gets up, strides for the door.

dialogues.speaker: DEMARKO
dialogues.text: (yelling after him) Hey, Rada, where you going? ...Albany.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A commercial flight lands, taxis towards a gate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alex moves though the airport with other passengers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A cab pulls up. Alex get out, enters the hotel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Delaney and her campaign aides. Last minute details on th Peter Veress debate. Clipboards. Pacing. Jokes.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID GARTH
dialogues.text: ...Sure, from his perspective he has nothing to lose.

dialogues.speaker: DELANEY
dialogues.text: I want to grind him, go over sixty percent on Tuesday.

dialogues.speaker: HAL RENNERT
dialogues.text: We may be vulnerable on the crime issue, he'll do the prosecutor Veress number.

dialogues.speaker: DELANEY
dialogues.text: That sounds like a Frank Willis remark. (glances over to Frank, smiles) I think I can hit the curve ball, Hal. Just throw back the statistics at him. Nobody's going to be listening to Peter Veress anyway, they're all going to be watching for that little tic. Some laughter. Except for Katharine. She seems preoccupie

dialogues.speaker: HAL RENNERT
dialogues.text: Every one of those little babies is worth at least a half a percentage point. Press guys have a pool on how many. More laughter.

dialogues.speaker: DELANEY
dialogues.text: (checks around) That everything? Okay, guys, I'd like to relax a little. Frank, Hal, David Garth and a FEW AIDES start packing up. Katharine lingers, moves to Delaney.

dialogues.speaker: DELANEY
dialogues.text: Katharine?

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: Maybe this isn't the best time?

dialogues.speaker: DELANEY
dialogues.text: What's up? Delaney strides toward the bedroom portion of the suite. Katharine follows. The men file out the door toward the hall.

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: Alfred met with Alex Rada yesterday.

dialogues.speaker: DELANEY
dialogues.text: Alfred's gotten him a position at Cargill, Finch.

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: What? You're joking? Alex Rada?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Delaney sits at a dressing table, turns toward Katharine.

dialogues.speaker: DELANEY
dialogues.text: I believe so. (beat) He's accepted. We thought that's what you'd want.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alex moving down the hallway toward the suite. Spots the coming out. They acknowledge him. Frank does a double-tak

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Alex. What are you doing here?
