dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Katharine in there? Frank grabs Alex by the arm. Alex shoots him a look. Fran lets go.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Let me buy you a drink, Alex.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: (hesitates; nods) Sure. Later, Frank, okay? I'll meet you in the bar. The last one out of the room is David Garth. Alex pushes him and into the suite.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alex doesn't immediately see anyone. He walks to the bedr door, spots Delaney and Katharine inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Delaney rotates her neck, as though she is tense, tired. see Alex in b.g. Delaney presses her fingers against the muscles of her ne stares at Katharine, almost nostalgically. Through the mi on the dressing table:

dialogues.speaker: DELANEY
dialogues.text: I've always wanted the best for you, Katharine... For the first time we see a softness in Delaney's eyes.

dialogues.speaker: DELANEY
dialogues.text: ...One last time?...like it used to be... (beat) ...massage my neck? Katharine moves her hands to Delaney's shoulders, feels t taut muscles. She does this apprehensively, and with a cu detachment -- an involuntary act which she has done befor Her motion stops. Katharine turns toward the bedroom entr Alex. She sees him. Startled. Delaney now turns, too.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: What's the matter, don't you recognize your old friend?

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: Alex! Alex -- staring at the two of them for a long moment. Comprehending more than Katharine does.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: (to Katharine) ...You're a real mess, honey. He moves into the room, glares at Delaney.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: (to Delaney) It was you, wasn't it? (a derisive laugh to himself) Had the wrong Lynch. Doyle was picking her up for you...EYouR and Susan Blake, not Alfred. Katharine -- confused, frightened. Pushing not to show it

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: What is he talking about?!

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: (to Katharine) The senator EdesignateR here wanted to hang Susan Blake's other lover. When she found out it was you, it was a whole other story. (staring hard at Delaney now) She tried to scare you into leaving for a while, or at least have me called off. -- Damage control was better downtown than with me, right Senator? Delaney doesn't respond. Alex glares at the two of them, then turns for the door.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: (as he moves) By the way, you're going to need a new chauffeur. Doyle's dead. ...Have a nice debate. Katharine watches Delaney through the mirror. Realizing.

dialogues.speaker: DELANEY
dialogues.text: (using the mirror to converse) Katharine? I would never hurt you, you know that. Just as you would never hurt me. A wave of revulsion washes over Katharine's face. She hol a moment, then storms out of the room. Delaney casually reaches for a brush, about to stroke her hair with it. SLAMS it down on the dresser. Rushes to cat up with Katharine.

dialogues.speaker: DELANEY
dialogues.text: Katharine! (checks herself; softer) Katharine, you needed a rest -- You need one now. I'm sorry about Susan Blake. If Jimmy...whatever Jimmy Doyle did to her, it's over now. (beat) Katharine, we're on our way.

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: You knew her.

dialogues.speaker: DELANEY
dialogues.text: Yes, I knew her. She was around the campaign, you know that.

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: You bitch! Jimmy Doyle. It was you -- Susan wouldn't let go... she told you, what? -- that she'd make it public? She wouldn't have, you know. She never would have. (beat) All she wanted was someone who'd care about her -- someone who wasn't after something. Susan needed decency in her life, there was never enough of that around...and you're incapable of decency.

dialogues.speaker: DELANEY
dialogues.text: (hard) It's you that doesn't understand. She was a duplicitous little tramp who'd do anything for her own benefit. She played a good game, Katharine. She fooled us both -- Don't you see I'd have too much to lose?

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: What've you done!?

dialogues.speaker: DELANEY
dialogues.text: You're confused. I haven't done anything. A frozen beat. Stunned monotone from Katharine.

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: You're not even contrite, are you?

dialogues.speaker: DELANEY
dialogues.text: Contrite? What would you like me to be EsorryR about? (beat) Contrition is bullshit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An area once known as the mall. State buildings surroundi a long rectangular wading pool. Desolate at night. This i the site of the Lynch-Veress debate. Two solitary figures set against the marble backdrop of the buildings, gusts of wind blowing an occasional bit of trash past their feet.

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: No one is going to believe you. First you say it's Alfred, then you say Delaney -- and what proof is there? Who's going to buy it?

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: No one has to buy it, Katharine. You can take it away from her -- the election is the most important thing in her life -- and all you have to do is pop the lid. Katharine folds her arms, glares at her own reflection in the pool.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Just say you were once Delaney Lynch's lover, that you knew she was having an affair with the girl that got killed. (beat) How do you think that would play?

dialogues.speaker: KATHARINE
dialogues.text: I didn't know about Susan and Delaney.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: You do now. Lights and a crowd coming from a building known as 'The E

dialogues.speaker: THE ENTRANCE TO THE EGG
dialogues.text: Photographers and press follow Delaney and her entourage the building. She's all smiles. Lots of NOISE. Lots of: "How'd you think you did?"; "Did you win that one, Delane "Remember me on Tuesday"; etc. Cars pull up, Delaney and the entourage get in. Frank Wil spots Alex and Katharine by the rectangular pool.

dialogues.speaker: RECTANGULAR POOL AREA
dialogues.text: Alex and Katharine watching as the lights fade, as the crowd disperses. Frank slowly moves toward them. The three of them together now. The wind whips up, chille by the marble and the desolation. WE HOLD.

dialogues.speaker: A MINI-CAM
dialogues.text: As we pull back, we can see the electronic and print pres at a news conference. We are in a conference room at the Albany Marriott. Frank Willis moves to a podium. He hasn't gotten much sle Katharine waits in back. Some REPORTERS sit, others stand

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN REPORTER
dialogues.text: Frank, is this going to be official?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: (sullen) Dr. Raines has a statement. We're not going to be taking questions.

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER
dialogues.text: C'mon, Frank, let's have a little cooperation.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Dr. Raines is going to read her statement. NOISE AND ACTIVITY from the press corp.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: If you'll be quiet boys and girls, we have a statement. Frank nods toward Katharine. She approaches the microphon

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (The scene should have a documentary, HAND-HELD CAMERA fe Buzzing with activity. Reporters scurry in the background Cables hastily strung about. A GABE PRESSMAN TYPE readies a stand-up. A reporter near him looks into a small monito near his feet. (THE DIALOG IN THE SCENE OVERLAPS).

dialogues.speaker: GABE PRESSMAN TYPE
dialogues.text: ...Do we have a feed?

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN REPORTER
dialogues.text: Okay, let me know when you're ready. Another reporter next to her, holds a mike and presses a finger to his earpiece. He's on air.

dialogues.speaker: ON-AIR REPORTER
dialogues.text: -- It looks that way. The disclosure by an aide to Delaney Lynch has apparently crippled this campaign, Tom. We see LIGHTS TURN ON AND OFF, other reporters, other sou bites like: "So close to the election"; "...a disaster fo this campaign"; etc. CAMERA SLOWLY PULLS AWAY from this scene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alex, his back to us, stares out the window. He wears a suit.

dialogues.speaker: THE STREET BELOW
dialogues.text: A few floors up. Across the street we see the New York Public library. Outside, in front of the building, a limo pulls up. A chauffeur opens the door for the man in back. man is Alfred Lynch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A SECRETARY walks in.

dialogues.speaker: SECRETARY
dialogues.text: Mr. Lynch is on his way up to see Mr. Wells. Will you be joining them? Alex turns toward the secretary. HE IS WEARING GLASSES.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: No, I don't think so.

dialogues.speaker: SECRETARY
dialogues.text: It's a shame about Mrs. Lynch. Awful, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Yeah, Awful. He moves to his desk, sits down. The secretary points to some boxes.

dialogues.speaker: SECRETARY
dialogues.text: Can I help you unpack?

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Don't bother, I won't be here that long. She gives him a strange look, shrugs, exits. Alex gazes out over the street to the library, to the stone lions guarding its entrance. Lost in thought. He watches a group of school children from some private academy marching up the steps, all in uniform, all in unison.
